"totalArticleCount": 238, "title": {"eng": "Tearful Coco Gauff exits Paris Olympics singles competition after controversial line call"}, "summary": {"eng": "Coco Gauff reacts as a call goes against her at the Paris Olympics.\n\nCoco Gauff looked to be cruising against Donna Veki\u0107 in her third-round singles match at the Paris Olympics. Then, all of a sudden, she wasn't.\n\nHaving been a point away from taking the first set at Roland Garros, Gauff had to watch the contest slip away from her, eventually succumbing to a 7-6(7) 6-2 upset defeat on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nThe most fraught moment of the match came midway through the second set when Gauff was"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 93}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 238}, "sentiment": 0.04313725490196085}
{"uri": "8251360554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:17:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:17:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:16:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.adn.com/sports/national-sports/2024/07/30/coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-with-the-chair-umpire-and-a-match-to-donna-vekic-at-the-paris-olympics/", "title": "Coco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics", "body": "PARIS -- The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nLater Tuesday, Gauff returned to the court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz and won a first-round mixed doubles match, 6-1, 6-7 (6), 10-5 against Nadia Podoroska and Maximo Gonzalez of Argentina to get to the quarterfinals. Gauff also is competing in women's doubles at the Paris Olympics with Jessica Pegula.\n\n\"At the end of the day, if anything, doubles make you want to go out there more. You don't want to ruin someone else's chances based off your mentality,\" Gauff said. \"Taylor and I were talking about it earlier: A medal is a medal. I have two other events I can possibly do that in, so I'm just focused on that.\"\n\nIn singles, it was Vekic who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want,\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "adn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anchorage Daily News"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251301347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:30:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:30:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:29:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.wptv.com/sports/olympics/coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-with-the-chair-umpire-and-a-match-to-donna-vekic-at-the-paris-olympics", "title": "Coco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics", "body": "Tennis star Coco Gauff has been selected as Team USA's female flag bearer for the Opening Ceremony of the Olympic Games Paris 2024. (Scripps News)\n\nThe scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nLater Tuesday, Gauff went back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz and won a first-round mixed doubles match, 6-1, 6-7 (6), 10-5 against Nadia Podoroska and Maximo Gonzalez of Argentina to get to the quarterfinals. Gauff also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn singles, it was Vekic who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "wptv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WPTV"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250825192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:26:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:26:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:25:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.today.com/news/paris-olympics/coco-gauff-loses-donna-vekic-umpire-tennis-2024-paris-olympics-rcna164252", "title": "Coco Gauff speaks out after loss at Paris Olympics and 'frustrating' argument with umpire", "body": "Coco Gauff competes in a women's singles third round tennis match during Day Four of the 2024 Paris Olympics on July 30, 2024, in Paris. Vegard Gr\u00f8tt / Sipa USA via AP\n\nThe scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nIt was Vekic, though, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want,\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "today.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TODAY.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. {"uri": "8251376864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:37:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:37:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:33:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2808068/", "title": "Tennis Olympics: Coco Gauff argues with chair umpire over loss - ExBulletin", "body": "PARIS (AP) The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. A refereeing decision she knew was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time on the Olympic Games in Paris.\n\nEven the location was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was the place where the reigning US Open Champion was eliminated in the third round of the Summer Games on Tuesday by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2. That is also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff performed in an almost identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\nThis year, there have been several times where I felt like I always had to stand up for myself on the court, Gauff said afterwards, again calling for video review to be used in tennis, as is the case in many other professional sports.\n\nI felt like he was calling it before I hit it, and I don't think the umpire disagreed, she said. I think he just didn't think it affected my swing, which I did.\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris. She is 20 years old and comes from Florida. She was seeded second at the Olympic Games in the singles and was the female United States flag bearer during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nLater on Tuesday, Gauff returned to the court with American teammate Taylor Fritz and won a first-round mixed doubles match, 6-1, 6-7 (6), 10-5, over Nadia Podoroska and Maximo Gonzalez of Argentina to reach the quarterfinals. Gauff also will compete in the women's doubles event at the Paris Olympics with Jessica Pegula.\n\nUltimately, if there's one thing, it's doubles that make you want to go. You don't want to ruin someone else's chances based on your mentality, Gauff said. Taylor and I talked about it earlier: a medal is a medal. I have two other events where I can potentially do that, so I'm just focusing on that.\n\nIn the singles, it was Vekic who received a lot of support from the stands early in the match, with chants of Don-na! Don-na! going off. When Vekic began her comeback from a 4-1 deficit, she responded to the applause by waving her arms above her head for more and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff hit a backhand winner and raised her hand, waving her fingers to ask the people in the stands to support her and they responded, which made Vekic smile wryly.\n\nWhen the disputed decision took place two games from the end of the match, Gauff was already far behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol ruled Vekic's shot in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to the referee to talk to him, after which the game was stopped for several minutes.\n\nI never dispute these calls. But he called it before I hit the ball, Gauff told Campistol. It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, only lost five games in totalBut her first Olympic singles tournament ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with temperatures above 32 degrees Celsius.\n\nThese points are big deals. Usually they apologize afterwards. So it's a little frustrating. The Sorry doesn't help you when the game is over, Gauff said. I can't say I would have won the game if I had won that point.\n\nEven before the problems surrounding the umpire's decision, Gauff had been unable to get off to a good start against Vekic, who was a semi-finalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point away from a 5-1 lead and serving for the opening set. But she failed to seal the deal, then squandered a pair of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic raced to the end of that set, and held her ground in the second.\n\nAn example of Vekic's superiority this afternoon: she won 33 games, compared to only nine for Gauff.\n\nI'm not going to sit here and say that one point affected the outcome today, Gauff admitted, because I was already on the losing side.\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set debate. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss during a conversation with Campistol and a supervisor who was on court for the conversation on Tuesday.\n\nIt happens to me all the time here at the French Open. Every time, Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other as she pleaded her case. This is the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not interfere, remaining on her side of the court and playing with her strings.\n\nIt's a very difficult situation. I personally thought the referee made a good decision because it came quite late, Vekic said after the game when asked what had happened. But I'll have to look at it again. It's difficult to know exactly at that moment.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and walked back onto the field to restart play, the fans booed the referee loudly and angrily.\n\nThe first point of the next match went to Gauff and the spectators cheered her wildly.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later the game was over.\n\nLast weekend Gauff spoke of her ambition to leave Paris with three medals, one from each of her events. That is not going to happen now.\n\nI want to come home with something, Gauff said Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-438714497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:35:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:35:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T09:38:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/30/coco-gauff-loses-argument-with-chair-umpire-match-/", "title": "Gauff loses argument with chair umpire, match to Vekic at Paris Olympics", "body": "PARIS -- The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nIt was Vekic, though, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more - and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament - she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles - ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals - one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-438487833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:24:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:24:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:16:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/30/coco-gauff-loses-argument-with-umpire-ousted-at-paris-olympics/74601707007/", "title": "Tearful Coco Gauff loses argument with umpire, ousted at Paris Olympics", "body": "Paris -- The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nIt was Vekic, though, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit.\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "detroitnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Detroit News"}, "authors": [{"uri": Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want,\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "thegrio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheGrio"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438345598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:20:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:20:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T08:41:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/sports/olympics/coco-gauff-loses-argument-with-chair-umpire-match-at-paris-olympics/507-e747287c-257f-4b61-a14e-8793b0b2fa96", "title": "Coco Gauff brought to tears during loss at Paris Olympics", "body": "Coco Gauff gestures as she plays against Donna Vekic during their women's singles third round match at the at the 2024 Summer Olympics.\n\nPARIS, France -- Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match Tuesday.\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe {"uri": "8250879755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:02:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:02:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:01:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/latest/coco-gauffs-dispute-with-chair-umpire-leads-to-defeat-against-donna-vekic-at-the-paris-olympics/4412/", "title": "Coco Gauff's Dispute with Chair Umpire Leads to Defeat Against Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics - Pehal News", "body": "PARIS -- The scenario felt very familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was convinced was incorrect. A chair umpire who wouldn't heed. Tears flowing down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a defeat, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the location was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the current U.S. Open champion was defeated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly indistinguishable dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There have been multiple instances this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, reiterating a call for video review to be utilized in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nIt was Vekic, however, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" echoing. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call occurred two games from the end of the match, Gauff was far behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never dispute these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, losing a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"", "source": {"uri": "pehalnews.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pehal News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8251213940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:14:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:14:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:13:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/olympics-2024-coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-wit-chair-umpire-and-match-to-donna-vekic/articleshow/112147266.cms", "title": "Olympics 2024: Coco Gauff loses argument with chair umpire and match to Donna Vekic", "body": "During a Paris Olympics third-round singles match, Coco Gauff argued with the chair umpire over a ruling, leading to tears, as she ultimately lost 7-6, 6-2 to Donna Vekic. The dispute occurred when a line judge initially called Vekic's shot out, but the umpire ruled it in, giving Vekic a crucial point. Gauff's frustration mounted after failing to sustain a strong start against Vekic, who dominated with 33 winners to Gauff's nine.Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match Tuesday. Gauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament - she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles - ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect - not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly - anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8251925362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:09:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:09:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:07:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/coco-gauff-paris-2024-olympics-line-call-controversy-chair-umpire-tears-video-review-vekic-loss/article68467612.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Gauff renews call for video reviews in tennis after line-call controversy in loss to Vekic", "body": "The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning US Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6(7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nLater Tuesday, Gauff returned to the court with US teammate Taylor Fritz and won a first-round mixed doubles match, 6-1, 6-7(6), 10-5 against Nadia Podoroska and Maximo Gonzalez of Argentina to get to the quarterfinals. Gauff also is competing in women's doubles at the Paris Olympics with Jessica Pegula.\n\n\"At the end of the day, if anything, doubles make you want to go out there more. You don't want to ruin someone else's chances based off your mentality,\" Gauff said. \"Taylor and I were talking about it earlier: A medal is a medal. I have two other events I can possibly do that in, so I'm just focused on that.\"\n\nIn singles, it was Vekic who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want,\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarShooting, Paris 2024 Olympics LIVE Score Updates, July 31: Aishwary Tomar, Swapnil Kusale in action in men's 50m 3 positionsTeam SportstarParis Olympics 2024: Italy silences French crowd to claim gold in women's fencing team event ReutersParis 2024 Olympics: Gauff renews call for {"uri": "8250815505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:20:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:20:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:18:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.espn.in/olympics/story/_/id/40679555/coco-gauff-ousted-paris-olympics-spat-umpire", "title": "Tearful Gauff argues with ump, loses at Olympics", "body": "PARIS -- The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning US Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday.\n\nThat's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while losing to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in a semifinal last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old American who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nShe hit a serve, and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official, and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the temperature rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit.\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nStill, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her racket strings.\n\n\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nGauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.\n\nOver the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\n\n\"I want to come home with something,\" Gauff said Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "espn.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251043452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:54:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13689435/Coco-Gauff-breaks-tears-spat-Olympics-umpire.html", "title": "Coco Gauff breaks down in tears after spat with Olympics umpire", "body": "American tennis star Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into a heated argument with an umpire before being dumped out of the women's singles at the Olympic Games. Gauff, the reigning US Open champion, lost 7-6 (7), 6-2 to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a third-round singles match in Paris on Tuesday.\n\nShe was already trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match, after the 20-year-old hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called the shot out after Gauff did not keep the ball in play. However, chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's effort landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nA furious Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes while an argument ensued. 'I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,' Gauff said to Campistol. 'It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.' Gauff was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in the women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius). Even before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nShe led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second. One measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff. But the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, she also got nowhere with the chair umpire during a similar dispute. After that match, Gauff called it 'almost ridiculous' that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday. 'It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,' Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. 'This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.'\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings. When Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official. The first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her. But about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? Visit our profile page and hit the follow button above for more of the news you need.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-438470660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:09:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:09:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/floridas-coco-gauff-loses-argument-paris-olympics/61739852", "title": "Florida's Coco Gauff loses argument with chair umpire at Paris Olympics", "body": "The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.Even the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"Related: Keep up with the Florida athletes at the Paris OlympicsGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.It was Vekic, though, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.By the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.She hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"Watch: Lady Gaga performs at Paris Olympics opening ceremonyShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"Even before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.The American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she didn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.More:Historical Data: How many Olympic athletes has Florida produced since 1952?One measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"Still, the most memorable moment in the match was that second-set argument. Gauff even alluded to that Swiatek loss while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"Vekic, who advanced to the quarterfinals, did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\"It's a very tricky situation. I personally thought the umpire made a good decision, because the call came quite late,\" Vekic said when asked afterward about what happened. \"But I'll have to rewatch it. It's tough to know exactly in the moment.\"When Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.The first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.But about 10 minutes later, the match was over.Gauff was scheduled to head back out on court with U.S. teammate Taylor Fritz for a first-round mixed doubles match later Tuesday. She also is competing in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula at these Olympics.Over the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events in Paris. That won't happen now.\"I want\" Gauff said Tuesday, \"to come home with something.\"\n\nThe scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Olympics.\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nRelated: Keep up with the Florida athletes at the Paris Olympics\n\nGauff is one of the biggest stars at the 2024 Paris Games, a 20-year-old from Florida who was seeded No. 2 at the Olympics in singles and was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nIt was Vekic, though, who was receiving much of the support from the stands early in the match, with chants of \"Don-na! Don-na!\" ringing out. When Vekic began her comeback after trailing 4-1, she responded to some applause by waving her arms overhead for more -- and the crowd responded. In the next game, Gauff delivered a backhand winner and raised a hand, wagging her fingers to ask the folks in the seats to back her -- and they responded, drawing a wry smile from Vekic.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind.\n\nShe hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nWatch: Lady Gaga performs at Paris Olympics opening ceremony\n\nShe easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games. But her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set.
