{"uri": "2024-07-437610654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:24:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:24:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:17:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.recordherald.com/2024/07/29/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always-been/", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th head-to-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad\" that she missed the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nMen moving into the third round included Carlos Alcaraz, who defeated Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands 6-1, 7-6 (3) on Monday night. Alcaraz needed a medical timeout for treatment from a trainer for a groin muscle issue in the second set, then was a point from getting pushed to a third, but finished the job.\n\n\"It's a pain that I've been dealing with,\" Alcaraz said, mentioning that it bothered him during his run to the Wimbledon championship this month. \"I know what I have to do ... to deal with this pain.\"\n\nAlcaraz, a 21-year-old who also won the French Open in June for one of his four Grand Slam titles, is scheduled to team with Nadal in doubles for Spain on Tuesday against Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\n\"I will try to recover as soon and as (best) as I can tonight,\" Alcaraz said, \"to be ... 100% tomorrow in my doubles.\"\n\nOther winners were Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, three-time major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champ Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won, but the fifth-seeded Pegula was eliminated from singles 4-6, 6-1, 6-3 by Tokyo Games bronze medalist Elina Svitolina of Ukraine in the day's last match. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nGauff, Collins and Navarro give the United States three women in the third round of Olympics singles for the first time since 2004, when Venus Williams, Lisa Raymond and Chanda Rubin did it at the Athens Games.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for Tuesday, as was the first-round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from three events.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Olympics.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal to Gauff, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"", "source": {"uri": "recordherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Record Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8250763926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:48:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:48:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:46:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-with-the-chair-umpire-and-a-match-to-donna-vekic-at-the-olympics-6150171.html", "title": "Sports News | Coco Gauff Loses an Argument with the Chair Umpire and a Match to Donna Vekic at the Olympics | LatestLY", "body": "Paris, Jul 30 (AP) Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match Tuesday.\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nAlso Read | India vs Sri Lanka Live Score Updates of 3rd T20I 2024: Toss Delayed Due to Rain.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nAlso Read | Ukraine vs Argentina Paris Olympics 2024 Free Live Streaming and Match Time in IST: How to Watch Free Live Telecast of UKR U-23 vs ARG U-23 on TV and Online Stream Details of Men's Football Match in India.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over. {"uri": "8249980336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "05:23:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T05:23:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T05:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/jul/29/gauffs-record-at-olympics-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always-been/", "title": "Gauff's record at Olympics perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory Monday against Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55 percent of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1\u00bd hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th head-to-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad\" she missed the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nMen moving into the third round included Carlos Alcaraz, who defeated Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands 6-1, 7-6 (3) on Monday night. Alcaraz needed a medical timeout for treatment from a trainer for a groin muscle issue in the second set, then was a point from getting pushed to a third, but finished the job.\n\n\"It's a pain that I've been dealing with,\" Alcaraz said, mentioning that it bothered him during his run to the Wimbledon championship this month. \"I know what I have to do ... to deal with this pain.\"\n\nAlcaraz, a 21-year-old who also won the French Open in June for one of his four Grand Slam titles, is scheduled to team with Nadal in doubles today for Spain against Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\n\"I will try to recover as soon and as (best) as I can tonight,\" Alcaraz said, \"to be ... 100 percent tomorrow in my doubles.\"\n\nOther winners were Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, three-time major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champion Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won, but the fifth-seeded Pegula was eliminated from singles 4-6, 6-1, 6-3 by Tokyo Games bronze medalist Elina Svitolina of Ukraine in the day's last match. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nGauff, Collins and Navarro give the United States three women in the third round of Olympics singles for the first time since 2004, when Venus Williams, Lisa Raymond and Chanda Rubin did it at the Athens Games.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for today, as was the first-round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from three events.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Olympics.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal to Gauff, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"", "source": {"uri": "newstribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jefferson City News Tribune"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8252324872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:14:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:14:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:13:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/paris-2024-coco-gauffs-emotional-breakdown-at-roland-garros-in-a-shocking-olympic-exit/", "title": "Paris 2024: Coco Gauff's emotional breakdown at Roland Garros in a shocking Olympic exit - MyJoyOnline", "body": "Coco Gauff of Team United States interacts with Clare Wood, Technical Official of the ITF during her Women's Singles third round match against Donna Vekic of Team Croatia on day four of the Olympic Games Paris 2024 at Roland Garros on July 30, 2024 in Paris\n\nCoco Gauff arrived to Paris as one of the icons of the USA team, was chosen as flagbearer alongside LeBron James in the Opening Ceremony, and started hitting the headlines as she became the youngest American woman to win a singles tennis match in the Olympics since Venus Williams.\n\nIn the first two games, won in straight sets, she barely conceded five games: three against Ajla Tomjlanovic (6-3, 6-0) and two against Maria Lourdes Carle (6-1, 6-1). So where, exactly, did it all go wrong for one of the potential Olympic stars?\n\nIt could be said that a wrong call by the umpire made her lose balance, but can a wrong call, one single point, make her collapse like a house of cards?\n\nVEKIC'S COMEBACK\n\nIt happened against a formidable and resilient Donna Vekic. The Croatian did not feel the pressure while Gauff's astounding record was adding a 4-1 and 5-2 in the first set. She came back, levelled 5-5 and 6-6, and ended up winning the tie-break 9-7, despite Gauff previously having two sets points. The last shot, out, already shown a stressed Gauff, who had let go a set that seemed won.\n\nKEY MOMENT\n\nBut the key moment was in the second set, when a ball was called out immediately before Gauff was about to hit it. Without video review, the umpire ruled out the judge call and, since Gauff's swing had not crossed the net, the point was given to Vekic.\n\nGauff couldn't believe it. She claimed she didn't hit the ball well because she heard the out call before. The umpire admitted she might be right, but that his decision was taken. Then Gauff said \"why does it always happen to me? On this court? I have to advocate for myself every time\".\n\nTEARS\n\nThe protest lasted more than a game. It took almost five minutes of arguments, with Gauff visibly emotional, and the match supervisor going down to the court. \"I never argue these calls but this is not fair! I feel like I'm being cheated\", she kept saying, in tears. The spectators were clearly supporting Gauff. But the decision stood, Gauff lost that game (break, 2-4) and she couldn't recover.\n\nThe game suddenly had a different atmosphere. Vekic was jeered and she, too, felt affected. \"It's not my fault!,\" she said to the public. She also needed some minutes to be back in her game and finish with a deserved 6-2.\n\nTIK-TOK PROTEST\n\nA day after the Opening Ceremony, Gauff complained on Tik-Tok about the living conditions of the Olympic Villa, as her post \"10 girls, 2 bathrooms\" went viral. \"All the tennis girls have now moved out, so there are 5 girls, 2 bathrooms now,\" she then added.\n\nWhile she still has chances in the doubles and the mixed doubles, the real dream was shattered too soon.\n\nGauff, a majestic champion, is still young and might have to learn to deal better with uphill conditions, even if some of them are unfair. She clearly had bad memories of Paris (very fresh memories) haunting her after what happened in Roland Garros one month ago. But in the mixed-zone, after cooling off, at least she admitted that even if that point was replayed, that wouldn't have meant that she'd won the game. It's a good restart after the storm.", "source": {"uri": "myjoyonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MyJoyOnline.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8249525416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:28:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always/article_ca99b89c-647b-5d62-b293-95810d629eb4.html", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th head-to-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad\" that she missed the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nMen moving into the third round included Carlos Alcaraz, who defeated Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands 6-1, 7-6 (3) on Monday night. Alcaraz needed a medical timeout for treatment from a trainer for a groin muscle issue in the second set, then was a point from getting pushed to a third, but finished the job.\n\n\"It's a pain that I've been dealing with,\" Alcaraz said, mentioning that it bothered him during his run to the Wimbledon championship this month. \"I know what I have to do ... to deal with this pain.\"\n\nAlcaraz, a 21-year-old who also won the French Open in June for one of his four Grand Slam titles, is scheduled to team with Nadal in doubles for Spain on Tuesday against Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\n\"I will try to recover as soon and as (best) as I can tonight,\" Alcaraz said, \"to be ... 100% tomorrow in my doubles.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nOther winners were Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, three-time major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champ Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for Tuesday, as was the first-round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from three events.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Olympics.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal to Gauff, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"\n\nAP National Writer Jenna Fryer contributed.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", However, the loss came in very controversial fashion.\n\nGauff was trailing in the second set 3-2 when she was facing a break point at 30-40. When the 20-year old stepped back in order to connect on a backhand shot, the linesperson ruled that the previous shot was out as she made contact with the ball.\n\nThe linesperson ended up awarding a point to Vekic, and Gauff was extremely displeased with the call. In fact, a five-minute argument unfolded in which Gauff pleaded her case and got extremely emotional.\n\nGauff could even be heard saying \"I feel like I'm getting cheated constantly in this game.\"\n\n\"I felt that they called it before I hit,\" Gauff said after the match. \"I don't think the ref disagreed. I think he just thought it didn't, like, affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR system because these points are big deals,\" Gauff added. \"Usually, afterwards they apologize. It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nFollowing the controversial point, Vekic managed to record break points and eventually took a 5-2 lead. Gauff was clearly rattled by the situation and never able to recover.\n\nGauff still has a chance to secure a gold medal in doubles and mixed doubles, but her Olympics singles journey is in the After Vekic's ball was called out - Gauff returned that ball and it landed in the net. After a quick inspection, the umpire determined that Vekic's ball was in. But he didn't decide the point to be replayed - instead chair umpire Jaume Campistol directly awarded the point to the Croatian.\n\nGauff couldn't believe the call - and after breaking down in tears and getting extremely upset - she demanded the supervisor. When the supervisor arrived on the court, Gauff emotionally asked when umpires would stop \"cheating\" on her.\n\n\"I feel like I'm getting cheated constantly in this game. This is the 3rd time this happens to me this year,\" Gauff was heard telling the supervisor.\n\nAfter a very controversial call and dramatic situation, Gauff didn't win a game afterward as Vekic completed a 7-6 (7) 6-2 win.\n\nGauff also felt wronged by umpires during one of her 2023 US Open and 2024 Dubai matches.\n\n\"There have been multiple times this year where that happened to me where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. {"uri": "2024-07-438398871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:08:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:08:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:29:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-coco-gauff-calls-out-umpire-frustrating-loss-donna-vekic", "title": "Coco Gauff calls out umpire after 'frustrating' loss to Donna Vekic", "body": "Coco Gauff is out of the women's singles draw at the 2024 Paris Olympics after losing 7-6 (7), 6-2 to Croatian Donna Vekic in a Round of 16 match that was marred by controversy on Tuesday morning.\n\nGauff lost the first set tiebreak despite being up 4-1, but things deteriorated for the American in the second set. After hitting a serve that Vekic returned close to the baseline while trailing 3-2 in the second, a line judge called the ball out right as Gauff was preparing to return the shot. But chair umpire Jaume Campistol believed the shot landed in, earning Vekic a massive service break and a 4-2 lead in the set.\n\nPlay was delayed for several minutes as Gauff argued with Campistol over the call, and the American flag bearer was in tears by the end of the exchange.\n\n\"I felt that they called it before I hit. I don't think the ref disagreed. I think he just thought it didn't, like, affect my swing, which I felt like it did,\" Gauff said, per The Athletic's Nicole Auerbach.\n\n\"There have been multiple times this year where that happened to me where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards they apologize. It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over. It's not fair at all. You guys are not fair to me and I hope one day that the game becomes fair but it's not.\"\n\nCoco Gauff admits she was unlikely to win match at that point\n\nThe match only lasted about 10 minutes after the exchange, with Vekic winning each of the next two games to advance to the quarterfinals. The 20-year-old Gauff was the No. 2 seed in Paris, winning her first two matches while dropping only five games. It was a tough matchup for her, as Vekic is fresh off an appearance in the Wimbledon semifinals earlier this month.\n\nVekic finished with 33 winners in the match, while Gauff hit just nine.\n\n\"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point. But being down a break... Maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game,\" said the reigning US Open champion, per Auerbach. \"But I'm not gonna sit here and say one point affected the result today, because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened.\"\n\nDespite being out of the singles draw, Gauff will continue her Olympics campaign with American Jessica Pegula in women's "eng-9770346", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039, "wgt": 199, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251001114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:24:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:24:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:23:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.bpr.org/npr-news/2024-07-30/team-usas-coco-gauff-exits-olympics-singles-tournament-with-a-third-round-loss", "title": "Team USA's Coco Gauff exits Olympics singles tournament with a third-round loss", "body": "U.S. tennis star Coco Gauff is out of the women's singles tournament at the Paris Olympics, after a dramatic straight-set loss to 13th-seeded Donna Vekic -- in a match that included an on-court controversy at Roland-Garros Stadium.\n\nGauff, the world's No. 2 player, was trailing Vekic 3-2 in the second set after a back-and-forth battle, but any bid for a potential comeback evaporated shortly after chair umpire Jaume Campistol overruled a line call in Vekic's favor.\n\nGauff had just served, and a line judge called Vekic's baseline return shot out at roughly the same time Gauff hit the ball into the net. But Campistol overruled the line call, resulting in a point for Vekic. Rather than deuce, the game went to Vekic, putting her ahead by 4-2.\n\nGauff then argued that the point should have been replayed, saying that hearing the \"out\" call had affected her shot. Campistol didn't agree. The 20-year-old Gauff -- who faced a similarly tough situation during the French Open at Roland-Garros earlier this summer -- grew emotional as she asked for what she saw as a fair resolution.\n\n\"It always happens to me on this court,\" Gauff told the umpire, adding later, \"I feel like I've been cheated on constantly.\"\n\nThe match was an abrupt turnabout for Gauff. A U.S. flagbearer in Friday's opening ceremony, she mostly breezed her way through the tournament's first two rounds. Against Vekic, she had built a 4-1 lead in the first set.\n\nBut then Vekic, the Croatian who earlier this month took part in the longest women's semifinal ever at Wimbledon, got into the fight. She eventually pulled even with Gauff at 6 games apiece to force a tiebreaker, using her forehand and efficient net play to overcome 27 unforced errors in the first set.\n\nGauff has two more chances to win an Olympic medal in Paris: she's playing women's doubles and mixed doubles. After the match, she said she will focus on doubles now.\n\n\"I want\" Gauff said according to The Associated Press, \"to come home with something.\"\n\nKnown for her composure and confidence that seem beyond her years, Gauff said that while the contested point was important, it might not have changed the outcome of Tuesday's match. But she repeated a call she made at the French Open earlier this year, saying tennis should follow other sports in implementing a video review system across all competitions.\n\n\"I definitely think that at this point it is almost ridiculous that we don't have it,\" she said in June.\n\nThe U.S. Open became the first Grand Slam tournament to add electronic line-calling, back in 2006. But officials at Roland-Garros have refused to implement line technology such as the \"Hawkeye\" system, saying that because of the red courts' unique conditions (read: dust), human judges and umpires are superior.\n\nMomentum has been building to add video review tools at Grand Slams in recent years: last summer, the U.S. Open installed the systems to test how they performed on some courts.", "source": {"uri": "bpr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "bpr.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donna_Veki\u0107", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donna Veki\u0107"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "French Open"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis", "type": {"uri": "8250737153", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:40:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:40:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:30:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13688683/Coco-Gauff-loses-argument-chair-umpire-match-Donna-Vekic-Paris-Olympics.html", "title": "Coco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match Tuesday.\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It\u00b4s not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nCoco Gauff of United States gestures as she plays against Donna Vekic of Croatiathe during their women's singles third round match at the Roland Garros stadium, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Andy Wong)\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament - she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles - ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn\u00b4t close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic\u00b4s superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect - not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly - anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nCoco Gauff of United States eyes on the ball as she plays against Donna Vekic of Croatiathe during their women's singles third round match at the Roland Garros stadium, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Andy Wong)\n\nCoco Gauff of United States reacts after scoring a point against Donna Vekic of Croatiathe during their women's singles third round match at the Roland Garros stadium, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Andy Wong)\n\nDonna Vekic of Croatiathe returns a shot to Coco Gauff of United States during their women's singles third round match at the Roland Garros stadium, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. {"uri": "8249322842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "17:22:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T17:22:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T17:22:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always-been/600387244/", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournament?\n\n''You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,'' the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n''I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,'' Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.''\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at her debut Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles, where her partner is Taylor Fritz. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from each event.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Games.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n''I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,'' Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.''\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "startribune.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8249421741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:49:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:49:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:48:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics-and-paralympics/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always/article_c98ca115-3167-5d38-9d2f-282b9e5dcd64.html", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th head-to-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad that I'm missing\" the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMen moving into the third round included Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals, while Carlos Alcaraz -- who is teaming with Nadal in doubles for Spain -- was playing Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands in singles at night.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, three-time major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champ Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for Tuesday, as was the first-round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from three events.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Olympics.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal to Gauff, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"\n\n___\n\nAP National Writer Jenna Fryer contributed.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "8251893776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:46:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:46:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:45:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Stories/147010/donna-vekic-on-coco-gauffumpire-drama-one-of-her-out-balls-wasn-t-called-what-now/", "title": "Donna Vekic on Coco Gauff-umpire drama: One of her out balls wasn't called, what now?", "body": "Vekic addresses the Gauff and chair umpire controversy following a Paris Olympics win over the American.\n\nDonna Vekic was lost for words about her huge victory over Coco Gauff but couldn't say much about the American's dispute with the chair umpire but added that she also felt wronged in one of the calls earlier in the set - but just moved on.\n\nOn Tuesday, Vekic continued her big summer after upsetting world No. 2 Gauff 7-6 (7) 6-2 in the Paris Olympics round-of-16 to reach her maiden Olympic quarterfinal.\n\nAlthough Vekic was coming off a Wimbledon semifinal run, there was no doubt that 2023 US Open champion Gauff was the favorite to win their Olympic match. But the 21st-ranked Croatian came out playing a very aggressive and courageous tennis, which led to a huge result.\n\n\"Emotional madness, I have no other words. Gauff plays amazing tennis all the time, especially on this surface which suits her better than me. This is my big success... Definitely in the Top 3 victories in my career. Coco on earth, but this is my biggest victory in my career,\" Vekic told Sportske Novosti after the match.\n\nToday, Vekic plays against Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk for a place in the semifinal in Paris.\n\nJust a few games before Vekic completed her win, a very controversial moment happened and a lengthy discussion ensued. With Vekic up by a set - leading 3-2 - and having a break point on Gauff's serve, one of the Croatian's balls was called out. Gauff returned that same ball and it didn't make it past the net.\n\nAfter checking the mark, chair umpire Jaume Campistol realized that Vekic's ball was actually in. But he didn't want to replay the point, instead he just awarded it to Vekic and that gave the Croatian a lead of a set and a break.\n\nGauff absolutely lost in those moments - and after an argument with Campistol - she had the supervisor come out. During her chat with the supervisor, the world No. 2 said that she feels \"cheated\" on in tennis constantly.\n\n\"This isn't fair. I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game. I constantly feel like that, and I have to argue. And then you guys apologize afterward. You guys say, 'I'm sorry,' and then what does that do for me in the match? It's not fair. Why am I on the bottom side of these calls?\" Gauff was heard saying on the court.\n\nFollowing her win, Vekic was asked to address the situation.\n\n\"It's hard for me to comment, I'll have to see what happened. During the match, I experienced this in a way that I won the game because the referee's call came very late. In the second game of the same set, she missed the serve and they didn't call it out. And what now? (laughs)\" Vekic said.\n\nAt one point, the crowd started booing Gauff because they wanted the match to continue. And after the argument was over and the clash continued, Vekic appeared to have lost her focus a bit and faced three consecutive break points on her serve. But not only that the Croatian managed to pull off that game, she also broke Gauff again in the eighth game to seal a 7-6 (7) 6-2 win.\n\n\"It was hard to keep focus on the game because the French are specific in their cheering and are extremely loud. But soon after that, they took my side again and helped me,\" Vekic said.\n\nMeanwhile, Gauff explained in her press what made her so frustrated on the court.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed. I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did,\" Gauff said.\n\nGauff wasn't happy at all with the call that was made against her midway through the second set but didn't want to blame that on her loss.\n\n\"It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over. I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point. But being down a break... Maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game,\" Gauff added.\n\n\"But I'm not gonna sit here and say one point affected the result today, because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened.\"", "source": {"uri": "tennisworldusa.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tennis World USA"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dzevad_mesic@tennisworldusa.org", "name": {"uri": "8251352654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:11:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:11:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:10:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10130212-coco-gauff-explains-umpire-dispute-after-olympics-loss-these-points-are-big-deals", "title": "Coco Gauff Explains Umpire Dispute After Olympics Loss: 'These Points Are Big Deals'", "body": "Coco Gauff spoke about the controversial call that cost her a crucial point in her straight-set loss (7-6, 6-2) to Donna Vekic in the third round of the women's singles tennis tournament at the Summer Olympics in Pris.\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said, per the Associated Press. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point.\"\n\nIn the second set, Gauff was serving down 3-2 (30-40) to Vekic. Gauff got her serve in, and Vekic returned a long one to the baseline. The linesperson initially ruled the ball out, and Gauff appeared to ease or check up after the call. She then hit the ball into the net.\n\nHowever, the chair umpire then issued a correction, calling the ball in. She then awarded the point to Vekic, giving her the set, the break and a 4-2 lead. Vekic then won the next two games for the victory.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" Gauff added. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nPer Matthew Futterman and Charlie Eccleshare of The Athletic, Olympic matches are ruled by the International Tennis Federation, and they cited a section in which cases like these are covered.\n\n\"If a chair umpire or line umpire calls 'Out' and then corrects the call to good, what is the correct decision?\" the rules read.\n\n\"Decision: The chair umpire must decide if the original 'Out' call was a hindrance to either player. If it was a hindrance, the point shall be replayed. If it was not a hindrance, the player who hit the ball wins the point.\"\n\nSo, in this case, the chair umpire apparently did not believe the out call was a hindrance to Gauff, who disagreed with the matter.\n\nUltimately, though, Vekic was the better player on this day, notably hitting 37 service winners go Gauff's 10. Gauff also had seven double faults to Vekic's three and zero aces to Vekic's five.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff said, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nDespite the defeat, Gauff is still alive in Olympic competition in women's doubles (with Jessica Pegula) and mixed doubles (with Taylor Fritz).", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8250927903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:34:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:34:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:33:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.newser.com/story/353664/coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-then-the-match.html", "title": "Coco Gauff Loses an Argument, Then the Match", "body": "The scene felt all too familiar to Coco Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. Even the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning US Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2 on Tuesday. That's also the main stadium for the French Open, reports the AP, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\nBy the time the disputed call happened two games from the end of the match, Gauff was way behind. She hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes. \"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority Tuesday afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff. \"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff acknowledged, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\" When Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly at the official. But about 10 minutes later, the match was over. Over the weekend, Gauff spoke about aiming to leave with three medals -- one from each of her events. {"uri": "8249335482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "17:33:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T17:33:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T17:32:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3034538-coco-gauffs-dominance-shines-at-paris-olympics-despite-errors", "title": "Coco Gauff's Dominance Shines at Paris Olympics Despite Errors | Sports-Games", "body": "Coco Gauff continues to impress at the Paris Olympics, defeating Argentina's Maria Lourdes Carle 6-1, 6-1 in the second round of singles. Despite numerous unforced errors and a low first-serve percentage, Gauff's aggressive play led to her victory. She aims for three medals in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles.\n\nCoco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces? So what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournament? \"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. ''So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\" Gauff is hoping to win three medals at her debut Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles, where her partner is Taylor Fritz. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from each event.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Games.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. ''Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. {"uri": "8250970731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:03:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:03:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:02:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thecut.com/article/coco-gauff-2024-olympics-match-umpire-argument.html", "title": "Coco Gauff Says She Gets 'Cheated on Constantly' in Tennis", "body": "Coco Gauff's Paris Olympics journey ended on Tuesday after a loss to Croatia's Donna Vekic. It was an emotional match owing to a shoddy call made by the umpire. For the third time this year, Gauff had to advocate for herself to the umpire, and this time she was left in tears.\n\nDuring the second set, Vekic returned Gauff's serve and the ball landed near the baseline. A line judge ruled the ball out, leading Gauff to return the ball into the net. The ball was actually in bounds, leading chair umpire Jaume Campistol to award a point to Vekic. His argument was that the \"out\" call from the line judge should not have affected Gauff's return.\n\nGauff objected to Campistol's call, eventually breaking into tears during the emotional argument. \"This isn't fair; he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff argued.\n\nIt seemed that Campistol understood that he had made a poor call because he told Gauff, \"I know I'm wrong, but I cannot change my decision after your appeal.\" Eventually, a referee came in to act as a mediator.\n\n\"This isn't fair. I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game. I constantly feel like that, and I have to argue. And then you guys apologize afterwards, you guys say, 'I'm sorry,' and then what does that do for me in the match?\" Gauff said. The ref argued that it was \"not intentional,\" which Gauff scoffed at. \"It's not intentional?' It happens to me, it happens to Serena ... It is.\"\n\nThroughout the heated exchange, Gauff made reference to the difficulties she's had with umpires this year. In February, she was forced to challenge a bad call at the Dubai Tennis Championships -- instead of being awarded a point, the ump made her redo the play. In June, at the French Open, Gauff missed a return after her opponent's serve was ruled out (sound familiar?). The umpire overruled the call, compelling Gauff to argue her side once again.\n\n\"There are so many decisions that are made, and it sucks as a player to go back or [watch] online, and you see that you were completely right,\" Gauff said of the French Open call. \"And it's like, what does that give you in that moment?\"\n\nBack at the Olympics, Gauff argued that the whole sport of tennis had a fairness problem. \"You guys are not fair to me,\" she said. \"I hope that one day the game becomes fair, but it's not.\"", "source": {"uri": "thecut.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Cut"}, {"uri": "8250683387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:58:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:58:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:58:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jul/30/it-always-happens-here-tearful-coco-gauff-disputes-call-during-olympic-tennis-exit", "title": "'It always happens here': Tearful Coco Gauff disputes call during Olympic tennis exit", "body": "Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire during her loss to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday.\n\nGauff, the reigning US Open singles champion, was trailing in the second set of her 7-6, 6-2 loss when she tangled with the umpire.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out, and Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving the Croatian a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes. \"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nThe American was seeded second in the women's singles in Paris and easily won her first two matches, dropping a total of just five games. But the 20-year-old's first Olympic singles tournament - she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles - ended with a performance that was far from her best on the hottest day of the Paris Games so far, with the heat rising above 32C (90F) during her match.\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semi-finalist at Wimbledon this month. Gauff led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second. One measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute. It's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect, and not the first time at Roland Garros, which hosts the French Open as well as this summer's Olympic tennis tournament.\n\nThere was a similar incident during Gauff's loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semi-finals last month. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events.\n\nShe alluded to the Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court on Tuesday. \"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly - with their anger seemingly directed at the officials. The first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her. {"uri": "2024-07-437423461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "17:44:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T17:44:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T17:17:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always/article_dbed4d51-0c1b-5eb5-b5e2-764d6660e69c.html", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournament?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at her debut Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles, where her partner is Taylor Fritz. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from each event.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Games.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"\n\nAP National Writer Jenna Fryer contributed.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe {"uri": "2024-07-437644180", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:37:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:37:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:11:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/donna-vekic-vs-coco-gauff-2024-olympics-tennis-prediction-odds-pick", "title": "Donna Vekic Vs Coco Gauff 2024 Olympics Tennis Prediction, Odds, Pick", "body": "Donna Vekic takes on Coco Gauff in the 2024 Olympics tennis women's singles tournament. Our 2024 Olympics tennis odds series has our Vekic Gauff prediction and pick. Find out how to watch Vekic Gauff.\n\nCoco Gauff steamrolled through her Monday match at the Paris Olympics, beating Maria Carle 6-1 and 6-1. It was the quick, clean, easy match Gauff needed with her other commitments in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula and in mixed doubles with Taylor Fritz. Any player who comes to the Olympics in all three tennis disciplines needs to be efficient in the early rounds against clearly inferior players so that there's enough energy in the tank and enough time to rest for other matches. It's true that players who are contenders in singles don't need to practice a lot if they also compete in doubles. The doubles matches are essentially the practice sessions between the singles matches. Players don't have to cover nearly as much of the court, and they can work on their net game and their volleys. It's in the singles matches where tennis players can't get overextended. Getting roped into a three-hour battle in singles will leave a player too taxed for doubles. Accumulated matches are likely to catch up to a player as the tournament goes on, which will endanger any hopes of getting an Olympic medal. The last thing Coco Gauff needs is for her singles matches to leave her wiped out for a quarterfinal or semifinal. That's how dreams of an Olympic medal can turn into a wrenching fourth-place finish, with no medal at all, let alone no gold medal.\n\nGauff's singles journey continues against Donna Vekic, who is riding high and playing some of the best tennis of her life. Vekic reached her first major tournament semifinal a few weeks ago at Wimbledon. Vekic came very close to making the final but was edged out by Jasmine Paolini in a very close (10-8) tiebreaker.\n\nHere are the Donna Vekic-Coco Gauff 2024 Olympics Tennis odds, courtesy of FanDuel.\n\n2024 Olympics Tennis Odds: Donna Vekic-Coco Gauff Odds\n\nThe veteran just made her first Wimbledon semifinal. Even though that was grass and this Olympic tournament is on red clay, it remains that Vekic is hitting the ball as confidently as she ever has in her career. She feels great about her game. She is not likely to win outright, but if she loses 6-4, 6-3, she will cover the spread. She is certainly playing well enough to keep this match close.\n\nWhy Coco Gauff Could Cover The Spread\n\nGauff is playing Olympic doubles and knows she has to conserve energy. That focus on the need to play quick, efficient matches was evident when she lost only two of 14 games to Carle in a beatdown. The spread for that Carle match was 6.5 games. Gauff won by 10. She is getting one more game to work with, being favored by only 5.5 games here. She can win by six or more games, no problem.\n\nFinal Donna Vekic-Coco Gauff Prediction & Pick\n\nGauff will win, but Vekic might cover. Ultimately, the spread seems well-chosen, and we're not sure how this will break. {"uri": "8250689792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:02:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:02:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5668338/2024/07/30/coco-gauff-olympics-tennis-donna-vekic/", "title": "Coco Gauff loses to Donna Vekic at Olympics after line call controversy", "body": "PARIS -- The top American tennis player Coco Gauff is out of the Olympic women's singles under controversial circumstances after a 6-7, 2-6 defeat to Croatia's Donna Vekic on Court Philippe-Chatrier at Roland Garros.\n\nA high-quality contest was overshadowed by a disputed line call at a crucial juncture in the second set, prompting Gauff to say, \"I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game,\" adding that \"it happens to me, it happened to Serena (Williams).\"\n\nAt 2-3, 30-40, Gauff served into Vekic's forehand, and as Gauff prepared to hit a return that went deep to the baseline, a linesperson called the ball out as the American swung for a forehand. Gauff pulled up and sent the ball into the net.\n\nThe chair umpire then overturned the point because Vekic's ball had landed in, giving her the break of Gauff's serve to go up, 4-2. That prompted Gauff to appeal that the call had hindered the completion of her swing.\n\nAfterward, Gauff, who was the flagbearer for Team USA alongside LeBron James, said that she \"felt that they called it before I hit.\n\n\"I don't think the ref disagreed. I think he just thought it didn't, like, affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\n\n\"There have been multiple times this year where that happened to me where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR (Video Assistant Referee) system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards they apologize.\n\n\"It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\n\"It's not fair at all. You guys are not fair to me and I hope one day that the game becomes fair but it's not,\" Gauff said in an extended back and forth with the chair umpire and the supervisor.\n\nPlay continued with Gauff down a break and she fought back in the next Vekic service game, but Vekic saved multiple break points, and ultimately cruised to an impressive victory by breaking Gauff again in the final game.\n\nVekic, who recently reached the Wimbledon semifinals for her best result at a Grand Slam, played well throughout, controlling points with monster forehands and a lethal drop shot. Down 5-3 in the first set, Vekic broke Gauff at love to turn the match around. She won the first-set tiebreak, 9-7, and recovered another early break in the second set to stay on serve.\n\nGauff, having been up in the first set, refused to attribute the loss to the call. \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point. But being down a break... Maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\n\n\"But I'm not gonna sit here and say one point affected the result today, because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened.\"\n\nGauff's Olympic campaign will continue with American No 2 Jessica Pegula in the women's doubles later today.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8250685237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:59:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://wtop.com/olympics/2024/07/coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-with-the-chair-umpire-and-a-match-to-donna-vekic-at-the-paris-olympics/", "title": "Coco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics - WTOP News", "body": "Gauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
