{"uri": "8251255505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:49:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:49:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:48:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-news/coco-gauff-olympics-emotional-debate-cheated-on-constantly-1235070781/", "title": "Coco Gauff Argues 'Unfair' Officiating Call During Tough Olympics Loss", "body": "Coco Gauff stopped her Olympics tennis match Tuesday to advocate for herself after an \"unfair\" call from a line judge that she said felt intentional.\n\nThe emotional argument with the chair umpire occurred during Gauff's third-round singles match against Croatia's Donna Vekic, who ultimately won in two sets.\n\nDuring the second set, Vekic hit a ball that landed near the baseline and a line judge ruled it out. As the line judge made their call, Gauff returned the ball into the net. But when Vekic's shot was actually ruled inbounds, the leading chair umpire, Jaume Campistol, awarded Vekic the point.\n\n\"This isn't fair. He called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff argued to Campistol.\n\nAs tears fell down her cheeks, Gauff continued: \"I never argue these calls but you called it out before I hit the ball. It always happens to me on this court. It always happens to me at French Opens every time... I always have to advocate for myself every time.\"\n\nLater, Campistol responded by saying, \"I'm not saying I'm right, but I'm just saying the way I'm seeing it... I know I'm wrong but I cannot change my decision after your appeal.\"\n\nA referee came in to mediate the argument as Gauff explained why the call was wrong from her point of view.\n\n\"This isn't fair. I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game. I constantly feel like that, and I have to argue,\" Gauff said. \"And then you guys apologize afterward. You guys say, 'I'm sorry,' and then what does that do for me in the match? It's not fair. Why am I on the bottom side of these calls?\"\n\nThe referee claimed the call was \"not intentional\" as Gauff responded, \"It's not intentional?' It happens to me, it happens to Serena ... It is.\"\n\nDuring the argument, Gauff appeared to allude to issues she faced in competitions earlier this year. There was one bad call at the Dubai Tennis Championship in February, but also an incident that occurred at the French Open -- on the exact same court as her match with Vekic -- in June. During that match, a loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek, Swiatek hit a serve that was called out just as Gauff was returning it. {"uri": "8249802742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "02:10:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T02:10:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T02:09:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/sports/coco-gauffs-record-at-the-paris-olympics-is-perfect-even-if-her-play-hasnt-always/article_b58aa224-4e00-11ef-84c7-8b063faf64dd.html", "title": "Coco Gauff's record at the Paris Olympics is perfect even if her play hasn't always been", "body": "PARIS -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th head-to-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad\" that she missed the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nMen moving into the third round included Carlos Alcaraz, who defeated Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands 6-1, 7-6 (3) on Monday night. Alcaraz needed a medical timeout for treatment from a trainer for a groin muscle issue in the second set, then was a point from getting pushed to a third, but finished the job.\n\n\"It's a pain that I've been dealing with,\" Alcaraz said, mentioning that it bothered him during his run to the Wimbledon championship this month. \"I know what I have to do ... to deal with this pain.\"\n\nAlcaraz, a 21-year-old who also won the French Open in June for one of his four Grand Slam titles, is scheduled to team with Nadal in doubles for Spain on Tuesday against Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\n\"I will try to recover as soon and as (best) as I can tonight,\" Alcaraz said, \"to be ... 100% tomorrow in my doubles.\"\n\nOther winners were Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, three-time major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champ Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won, but the fifth-seeded Pegula was eliminated from singles 4-6, 6-1, 6-3 by Tokyo Games bronze medalist Elina Svitolina of Ukraine in the day's last match. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nGauff, Collins and Navarro give the United States three women in the third round of Olympics singles for the first time since 2004, when Venus Williams, Lisa Raymond and Chanda Rubin did it at the Athens Games.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for today, as was the first-round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. {"uri": "8251481218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:39:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:39:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.cbs8.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-tonight/coco-gauff-cries-during-argument-with-chair-umpire-during-eliminating-match-at-the-paris-olympics/603-53a12122-2829-4e1a-b1ff-4124986842d8", "title": "Coco Gauff Cries During Argument With Chair Umpire During Eliminating Match at the Paris Olympics", "body": "Coco Gauff had a difficult loss that left her overcome with emotion and out of the Paris Olympics Women's Singles on Tuesday.\n\nFacing off against Croatia's Donna Vekic at Stade Roland Garros, the 20-year-old Grand Slam champion fell short 6-7, 2-6. Midway through the match, Gauff became emotional as she challenged chair umpire Jaume Campistol, during a five-minute dispute in which she challenged a call that the umpire ruled out before she had the chance to hit it.\n\nThe umpire ruled in favor of Vekic and awarded her the point, to the dismay of the crowd. Gauff continued to trail her opponent and could not recover a win.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" she said. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself,\" Gauff said during the dispute as she wiped away tears.\n\nAfter the match, Gauff spoke to reporters where she shared that tennis needs a video review system.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" she later told reporters via CNN. \"And I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR [video review] system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards, they apologize, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff faced an issue similar to this one in June during the French Open.\n\nWhile she is out of the Women's Singles, Gauff still has a chance to get a medal for U.S. Tennis as she plays in the doubles and mixed doubles competition.\n\nGauff's loss came after a night of celebration and showing off her official Snoop Dogg Paris Olympics pin.\n\nOn Monday night, Gauff showed off the pin on her Instagram Story, writing, \"I win the pin game.\"\n\nGauff's first Olympics started off historic as she joined LeBron James as the official flag bearer during the opening ceremony. Following the ceremony, Gauff took to X (formally known as Twitter) to celebrate the occasion.\n\n\"I just want to say thank you to my fellow team usa olympians/athletes for voting and choosing me for this incredible honor to be the flag bearer for the opening ceremony \u2764\ufe0f,\" she wrote. \"Thank you so much. Vekic slammed a forehand into the net and gave Gauff a two-break lead.\n\nMATCH STATS\n\nBefore long, Vekic turned up her tennis and pushed Gauff to a tiebreak for Set 1. Vekic's forehand was on fire and she used it to land an impressive 11 winners, taking the tiebreak and the set.\n\nBut it was the second set that dismantled Gauff's game entirely.\n\nAt 3-2, Gauff was on service when Vekic returned a forehand shot that a line judge called \"out\" as Gauff was striking the ball. The call seemed to cause Gauff to hit into the net. After Gauff made contact, the chair umpire called for a correction to the out call, thus making Vekic's shot in and Gauff's return shot a fault.\n\nGauff immediately approached the chair umpire to dispute the point.\n\n\"You called the ball out before I even hit the ball,\" Gauff emphatically told the ref.\n\n\"That doesn't matter,\" the chair umpire responded.\n\nAs Gauff and the umpire began to debate the point and call, the ITF tournament referee Clare Wood, came on court, and Gauff had choice words for her.\n\n\"It always happens to me on this court,\" Gauff relayed to the tournament referee. \"I feel like I've been cheated on constantly,\" Gauff noted, as tears streamed down the 20-year-old's face.\n\n\"I hope one day the game becomes fair because it's not,\" Gauff added before returning to the court.\n\nAs Vekic began her next service game, she was met with audible jeers.\n\n\"I did nothing wrong,\" Vekic could be seen saying on the court, in response to the crowd.\n\nGauff couldn't find her footing after the controversial call. {"uri": "8250689144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:03:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:03:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:01:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics-and-paralympics/coco-gauff-loses-an-argument-with-the-chair-umpire-and-a-match-to-donna-vekic/article_b6ea8836-4257-5a84-a383-c2514d08956a.html", "title": "Coco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff was left in tears after getting into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match Tuesday.\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old American, already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nGauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nGauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament -- she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles -- ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32 Celsius).\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe American led 4-1 and was a point from moving ahead 5-1 and serving for the opening set. But she couldn't close the deal, then wasted a couple of set points at 6-4 in the ensuing tiebreaker. Vekic surged to the end of that set, then maintained her level in the second.\n\nOne measure of Vekic's superiority on this afternoon: She finished with 33 winners to just nine for Gauff.\n\nBut the most memorable portion of the match was the second-set dispute.\n\nIt's not the first time Gauff has been upset by a call she thought was incorrect -- not even the first time in Court Philippe Chatrier, the main stadium used for the annual French Open Grand Slam tournament that was also the site Tuesday.\n\nDuring her loss to eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the French Open semifinals last month, a similar thing happened to Gauff. She argued. She also got nowhere with the chair umpire. After that match, Gauff called it \"almost ridiculous\" that tennis does not employ video replay technology at all events, the way many other sports do.\n\nShe alluded to that Swiatek match while talking to Campistol and a supervisor who joined the conversation on the court Tuesday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said, holding a tennis ball in one hand and her racket in the other while pleading her case. \"This is like the fourth, five time it's happened this year.\"\n\nVekic did not get involved, staying at her end of the court and fiddling with her strings.\n\nWhen Gauff gave up and headed back on court to resume play, fans booed loudly -- anger directed at the official.\n\nThe first point of the next game went Gauff's way, and spectators cheered wildly for her.\n\nBut about 10 minutes later, the match was over.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "8250769073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:50:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.amny.com/sports/coco-gauff-bounced-olympics-7-30-24/", "title": "Olympics 2024: Coco Gauff bounced from 3rd round in straight sets after controversial call | amNewYork", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Tennis - Women's Singles Third Round - Roland-Garros Stadium, Paris, France - July 30, 2024. Coco Gauff of United States talks with an official during her match against Donna Vekic of Croatia. REUTERS/Edgar Su\n\nCoco Gauff, the No. 2 ranked women's tennis player in the world and defending US Open champion, was bounced from the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris on Tuesday, losing in straight sets to Donna Vekic of Croatia, 7-6(7), 6-2.\n\nIn the sweltering heat at Roland Garros -- the iconic home of the French Open -- the 20-year-old American let a 5-2 lead in the first set slip away as Vekic saved three set points and then took the tiebreak.\n\nThe second set saw Vekic break Gauff in more ways than one in the sixth game to take a 4-2 lead. On a breakpoint for Vekic, a return headed for the baseline toward Gauff was called out by the referee before the American could return it. It prompted Gauff to miss the shot but after a review, the ball was deemed to be in, awarding the point to Vekic.\n\nGauff argued for several minutes with the referee and the umpire and broke down into tears. Vekic went on to win the next two games and the match for the upset.\n\nNBC microphones could pick up Gauff saying, \"It always happens to me on this court. I have to advocate for myself every time.\"\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me,\" Gauff said after the match. \"I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed. I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt it did.\"\n\nGauff's frustration had been slowly building on a day that saw her commit 21 unforced errors and seven double faults. She won just two of 11 net points and did not record an ace the entire match.\n\nDespite the loss, Gauff's Olympics are not over yet. She is competing in both the women's doubles and mixed doubles in Paris.\n\n\"I want to come home with something,\" Gauff said alluding to the prospects of winning a medal.", "source": {"uri": The 20-year-old appeared convinced the Spanish umpire was dead wrong about a decision, arguing passionately through a language barrier for close to 10 minutes.\n\n\"The fans let Gauff know it was time to move on by booing her back into competition, but the damage was done as she could not claw her way back - as Vekic had to do in the first set.\"\n\nThe results on Tuesday surprised many considering how well she did in the first two rounds of the tournament and her previous feat on the clay of Roland Garros where she reached the French Open final in 2022.\n\nGauff believes she was cheated and stressed why tennis should use a video replay system to handle situations like hers. \"I mean there's been multiple times this year where that happened to me where I feel like I always have to be, you know, an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said. \"And I feel like in tennis we should have a (review) system because, you know, these points are big deals. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol overturned the call and awarded the point to Vekic.\n\nThe point earned Vekic the decisive break in the second set and the Croatian took the next two games to win the match after Gauff argued with the umpire and broke into tears.\n\nThe 20-year-old, who was America's flagbearer at the opening ceremony along with LeBron James, was the second seed and had set her sights on singles gold.\n\nIn her confrontation with the umpire, Gauff said: \"I never argue these calls but he called it out before I hit the ball. It always happens to me on this court!\n\n'Call the supervisor. It always happens to me, every time. You understand that I always have to advocate for myself, all the time. I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nLater, Gauff renewed calls for video reviews to be used in tennis, adding: \"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\n\n\"These points are big deals. Usually afterward, they apologize. So it's kind of frustrating. The 'Sorry' doesn't help you once the match is over. Team USA's flagbearer Gauff is still active in all three disciplines this week: women's singles, women's doubles and mixed doubles.\n\nThis was the first professional meeting between Gauff and Carle, but they had faced off twice before during their successful junior careers. Gauff won both of those matches, in the 2017 Junior US Open semifinals and the Round of 16 at 2018 Junior Wimbledon.\n\nWorld No.2 Gauff maintained initial command in their rivalry on her way to a 5-0 lead on Monday. Carle did make the American work to close out the one-set lead, holding three break points at 5-1 before Gauff finally converted her fourth set point.\n\nAt 5-1 in the second set, Gauff slammed a backhand crosscourt winner to earn her first match point, which she converted when Carle found the net with a forehand error. Gauff converted six of her eight break points on Monday, while only dropping serve once.\n\nIn the Round of 16, Gauff will have her first career meeting with No.13 seed Donna Vekic of Croatia. {"uri": "2024-07-438417610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:22:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:22:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:48:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_a92292e0-9073-55cc-996c-9c3a7e9d2209.html", "title": "Tearful Gauff calls for video replays after stormy Olympic exit", "body": "Coco Gauff demanded the introduction of video replays at Roland Garros after being dumped out of the Olympic Games singles tennis tournament on Tuesday in a stormy defeat to impressive Donna Vekic of Croatia.\n\nVekic came through 7-6 (9/7), 6-2 to reach the quarter-finals after world number two Gauff became embroiled in a tearful, bitter dispute with the chair umpire over a line call in the sixth game of the second set.\n\nGauff, who had already surrendered a 5-2 lead in the first set, lost her composure on break point when a ball from Vekic was called out.\n\nHowever, Gauff then hit the return into the net as the chair umpire Jaume Campistol was correcting the original call.\n\nHe insisted the call had not hindered the American's shot.\n\nThe 20-year-old wept as she pleaded her case but the point and break was awarded to Vekic.\n\nGauff then called for the introduction of video replays to adjudicate controversial calls.\n\nThe French Open venue is the only one of the four Grand Slams that does not utilise technology in any form as officials believe electronic aids are not accurate on dusty clay courts.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me,\" Gauff, a runner-up at the French Open on the same Court Philipper Chatrier in Paris in 2022.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR (video review) system because these points are big deals. And, yeah, usually afterwards, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff added: \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nThe American star had also argued with the chair umpire during her semi-final loss to Iga Swiatek at the French Open last month.\n\nAgain, the dispute centred on a line call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" Gauff, who played a starring role at the Games opening ceremony on Friday where she carried the US flag with basketball superstar LeBron James, told the umpire on Tuesday.\n\n\"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nVekic, the first Croatian woman in the Olympic singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996, said the controversial incident was a \"very tricky situation\".\n\n\"I personally thought the umpire made a good decision because the call came quite late,\" said the 28-year-old Wimbledon semi-finalist.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the incident, Vekic had to save three break points in the seventh game as her momentum was checked by the delay.\n\n\"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in that game because it was an important game,\" she said.\n\nVekic will face either Marta Kostyuk or Ukraine of Greece's Maria Sakkari for a place in the semi-finals.\n\nGauff, who sat out the delayed {"uri": "8250238995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "08:29:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T08:29:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T08:27:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/coco-gauff-is-making-it-look-easy-for-u-s/article_ec2ff253-8ec1-54ff-bd52-5bf6a51f8b79.html", "title": "Coco Gauff is making it look easy for U.S.", "body": "PARIS -- Coco Gauff is making it look easy at the Paris Olympics so far, adding a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina in the second round of singles Monday to her growing collection of lopsided results.\n\nSo what if Gauff had more than twice as many unforced errors, 26, as winners, 11? So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't. Look at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\nPeople are also reading... The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Versatile Elliott to see plenty of the field for Vikings Owens will be missed at annual Creeper Trail Ride to End Cancer Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival BHC SOFTBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: Muncy completes stellar career with state title at Rye Cove Drug probe leads to arrests, seizure of $1.9M of meth, fentanyl This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage Candidate Cao meets with Republicans in Abingdon OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition Southwest Virginia economy resilient in face of population declines BHC BASEBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: Adversity didn't keep Lebanon's Dagan Barton from big season on diamond HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: All Wolves now playing at West Ridge\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was beating Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4 in the 60th headto-head matchup between two rivals with 46 Grand Slam titles between them.\n\nGauff said she was \"kind of sad\" that she missed the chance to watch a contest between two players who \"mean a lot\" to their sport.\n\nMen moving into the third round included Carlos Alcaraz, who is scheduled to team with Nadal in doubles for Spain on Tuesday and defeated Tallon Griekspoor of the Netherlands 6-1, 7-6 (3) in singles on Monday night. Alcaraz needed a medical timeout for treatment on a hip in the second set, then was a point from getting pushed to a third, but finished the job.\n\nAlcaraz won the French Open last month for his third Grand Slam title, then added a fourth at Wimbledon this month.\n\nOther winners were Casper Ruud of Norway and Stefanos Tsitsipas of Greece, who both have reached French Open finals.\n\nIn other action around the same facility used for the French Open, where Nadal won 14 of his 22 major championships, threetime major champion Angelique Kerber was a 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 winner against Jaqueline Adina Cristian of Romania, and Wimbledon champ Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic and Wimbledon runner-up Jasmine Paolini of Italy advanced in straight sets.\n\nGauff's American teammates Danielle Collins and Emma Navarro both won. Collins eliminated 2018 Australian Open title winner Caroline Wozniacki 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.\n\nThe next opponent for Gauff will be Donna Vekic, a Croatian who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon a little more than two weeks ago and got past 2019 U.S. Open champion Bianca Andreescu of Canada 6-3, 6-4 on Monday.\n\nGauff vs. Vekic was scheduled for Tuesday, as was the first round match for Gauff and Taylor Fritz in mixed doubles.\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at these Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from three events.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Olympics.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal to Gauff, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I'm just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "8251253285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:47:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:47:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:46:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.nbcolympics.com/news/what-happened-coco-gauff-vs-donna-vekic-paris-olympics", "title": "What happened to Coco Gauff vs. Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics?", "body": "Coco Gauff's run in the women's singles tournament in Paris came to a crashing halt Tuesday following a last-minute call reversal in her match against Croatia's Donna Vekic.\n\nToward the end of the second set -- with Gauff down 2-3, 30-40 -- Vekic returned a forehand shot that was ruled out by a line judge as Gauff was striking the ball. Because of the call, which typically ends a point, Gauff didn't finish her stroke properly, resulting in the ball hitting the net. After Gauff made contact, the chair umpire called for a correction to the out call. The correction ruled Vekic's shot to be in and Gauff's return shot a fault. The result would put Vekic up a break.\n\nGauff immediately disputed the point with the chair umpire.\n\n\"You called the ball out before I even hit the ball,\" the 20-year old emphatically told the ref.\n\n\"That doesn't matter,\" the chair umpire responded.\n\nAfter a short time, International Tennis Federation tournament referee Clare Wood came on court, causing Gauff to change the target of her challenges.\n\n\"It always happens to me on this court,\" Gauff noted as tears streamed down her face. \"I feel like I've been cheated on constantly. I hope one day the game becomes fair because it's not.\"\n\nThough the crowd seemed to be on Gauff's side, hurling criticisms at Vekic as the two returned to play, the American was unable to regain the composure with which she began the tournament, eventually losing the second set.", "source": {"uri": "nbcolympics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "nbcolympics.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8250961741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:57:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:57:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:56:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/2024-paris-olympics-coco-gauff-calls-for-video-review-after-emotional-run-in-with-umpire-in-loss-to-donna-vekic-153229833.html", "title": "2024 Paris Olympics: Coco Gauff calls for video review after emotional run-in with umpire in loss to Donna Veki\u0107", "body": "Coco Gauff lost her Round 3 match against Croatia's Donna Veki\u0107 on Tuesday. While she took full responsibility for her disappointing early elimination, she called out the chair umpire Jaume Campistol and called for more video replay in tennis following an intense and tearful on-court argument near the end of the match.\n\nGauff was battling for her life in the second set after Veki\u0107 came back from 5-1 to win the first. She hadn't been able to regain the calm strength she had displayed in the previous set, but what happened next sent her spiraling. She served the ball to Veki\u0107, and the return landed on the baseline. The line judge called the ball out at first, so Gauff didn't keep the ball in play. But the chair umpire disagreed and overruled the line judge, giving Veki\u0107 the point and a service break, making any comeback for Gauff even harder. Gauff walked over to Campistol and the pair argued for five minutes, with Gauff in tears, before the match resumed.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" Gauff told the media following the match. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nVeki\u0107 was already ahead by several games when Gauff had the argument with the chair umpire. By that point, Gauff's game had already fallen apart, and she admitted that she didn't know whether the point going her way would have changed anything.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today,\" Gauff said, \"because I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nWhether she would have won or lost isn't the point of her comments or her anger on the court. It's about the rules of the sport being applied correctly to every player. And it's not the first time she's felt this way.\n\n\"It always happens here at the French Open to me. Every time,\" Gauff said to Campistol during the argument. \"This is like the fourth, fifth time it's happened this year.\"\n\nThere's proof this has happened to her at least one other time in the past three months alone. At the French Open in May, pretty much the same exact situation unfolded when she was playing Iga Swiatek in the semifinals. She lost that match at well.\n\nBut all is not lost for Gauff at the 2024 Olympics. She's out of singles, but she is playing mixed doubles with Taylor Fritz, who is also competing in men's singles. Gauff is also continuing her longtime pairing with Jessica Pegula, who lost her second-round singles match earlier this week. Gauff and Pegula are seeded No. 1 in women's doubles, and just recently won their first Grand Slam doubles title at the French Open.\n\nBetween her partnerships with Pegula and Fritz, it's possible Gauff could leave the game with at least one gold. It may not be in singles, but gold is still gold, no matter the event.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438468831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:06:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:06:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:47:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://athlonsports.com/olympics/coco-gauff-demands-rule-change-after-emotional-olympic-disqualification-due-to-controversial-call", "title": "Coco Gauff Demands Rule Change After Emotional Olympic Disqualification Due to Controversial Call", "body": "American superstar Coco Gauff certainly didn't see her 2024 Summer Olympics bid ending this way.\n\nEarly on Tuesday morning, Gauff fell to Donna Vekic in the third round of the singles tournament, and it was largely in part to a controversial call made by an official that swung the momentum of the match and left Gauff in tears.\n\nDuring the match, the umpire called a ball out before Gauff could return it, making the call in her backswing. That caused the American to miss her shot. However, Gauff believed that the ball was in and that the missed call interfered with her attempt.\n\nAfter arguing the call for quite a while, Gauff ultimately walked away with frustrated tears in her eyes after proclaiming to herself that \"this always happens to me on this court.\"\n\nWhile there's nothing that Gauff can do about this one call in particular or her current standings in the 2024 Summer Games, she is attempting to lobby for change in the future by bringing in a better replay system for the sport of tennis.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR system because these points are big deals,\" Gauff said, per NBC's Nicole Auerbach. \"Usually, afterward they apologize. It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nHaving someone with Gauff's standing -- she was the Team USA flag-bearer alongside LeBron James -- eliminated {"uri": "8251143544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:13:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:13:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:12:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2484291/olympic-heartbreak-coco-gauff-single-dream-dashed-by-disputed-umpire-decision", "title": "Olympic heartbreak: Coco Gauff single dream dashed by disputed umpire decision", "body": "American tennis star Coco Gauff was eliminated from the women's singles competition at the Paris Olympics after a controversial call by the umpire.\n\nGauff lost to Croatian Donna Veki\u0107 7-6(7) 6-2 in a match filled with emotional highs and lows on Court Philippe-Chatrier at Roland Garros on Tuesday.\n\nInitially, Gauff appeared to be in control of the match. She was a point away from winning the first set, but the match quickly turned against her.\n\nThe No. 2 seed became embroiled in a heated argument with chair umpire Jaume Campistol, which contributed to her eventual straight-sets defeat.\n\nThe turning point came late in the match when Gauff was two games from the end. A line call on her baseline was initially called out, but Campistol overruled the decision, giving Veki\u0107 a crucial break point.\n\nGauff argued that the call was made just before she hit the ball, affecting her stroke. She pleaded for the point to be replayed, stating, \"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball. It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nThe debate paused the match for several minutes, with Gauff wiping away tears as the supervisor joined the discussion on the court. The crowd expressed their displeasure with boos and jeers.\n\nGauff later reflected on the incident, saying, \"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court.\" She renewed her call for the introduction of video review in tennis, similar to other professional sports.\n\nGauff emphasised that she believed the call impacted her swing. \"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nThe most emotional moment of the match occurred during the second set when Gauff broke down in tears during the argument with Campistol. Despite her efforts, the call stood, and play resumed to Gauff's detriment. She expressed her frustration with the situation, highlighting the need for technological support in tennis officiating.\n\n\"Usually, afterward, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over,\" Gauff said.\n\nGauff, a prominent figure at the 2024 Paris Games and the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony, faced a disappointing end to her singles campaign. However, her Olympic journey is not over. She is set to compete in mixed doubles with US teammate Taylor Fritz and in women's doubles with Jessica Pegula.\n\nThe incident with Campistol has sparked discussions about the fairness and accuracy of officiating in tennis. Gauff's call for video review resonates with many who believe that technological advancements could help prevent such controversies in the future. The young athlete's composure and advocacy for fair play have garnered widespread support, underscoring her role as a significant voice in the sport.\n\nAs Gauff continues her pursuit of Olympic success in doubles, her experience serves as a reminder of the emotional and psychological challenges athletes face in high-stakes competitions. Despite the setback, her resilience and determination remain evident, reflecting the spirit of the Olympic Games. Gauff's journey, both on and off the court, continues to inspire fans and fellow athletes alike, highlighting the importance of fairness and integrity in sports.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", {"uri": "8251023423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:40:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:40:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:39:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.oann.com/newsroom/coco-gauff-brought-to-tears-after-argument-with-chair-umpire-over-controversial-call-in-heartbreaking-olympics-loss/", "title": "Coco Gauff Brought To Tears After Argument With Chair Umpire Over Controversial Call In Heartbreaking Olympics Loss", "body": "American tennis star Coco Gauff was brought to tears during her 7-6 (9-7), 6-2 loss to Croatian player Donna Veki\u0107 in the third round of the tournament on Tuesday after an intense argument with the chair umpire of the match.\n\nGauff smashed a serve during the second set before Veki\u0107 returned it with a shot that landed near the baseline.\n\nBefore the 20-year-old American could return, a linesperson initially called it out.\n\nHowever, in a stunning result, chair umpire Jaume Campistol called the shot in, and awarded Vekic the point, which extended her lead to 4-2 in the set.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff told Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nThe argument that happened in two games from the end of the match caused Gauff to break out into tears.\n\nGauff initially held a 4-1 lead over Veki\u0107 in the first set. But the Croatian, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon earlier this year, came back and defeated her in a tiebreaker.\n\nLast month, Gauff had a similar situation happen to her when she disputed a call during her French Open loss to Iga Swiatek.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, asking for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"\n\nGauff entered the tournament as the No. 2 seed in the women's singles and made it look easy in her first two matches, only dropping a total of five games.\n\nHowever, the American's time in the Olympics is not done. And, yeah, usually afterwards, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff added: \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nThe American star had also argued with the chair umpire during her semi-final loss to Iga Swiatek at the French Open last month.\n\nAgain, the dispute centred on a line call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" Gauff, who played a starring role at the Games opening ceremony on Friday where she carried the US flag with basketball superstar LeBron James, told the umpire on Tuesday.\n\n\"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\n'Very tricky situation'\n\nVekic, the first Croatian woman in the Olympic singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996, said the controversial incident was a \"very tricky situation\".\n\n\"I personally thought the umpire made a good decision because the call came quite late,\" said the 28-year-old Wimbledon semi-finalist.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the incident, Vekic had to save three break points in the seventh game as her momentum was checked by the delay.\n\n\"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in that game because it was an important game,\" she said.\n\nVekic will face either Marta Kostyuk or Ukraine of Greece's Maria Sakkari for a place in the semi-finals.\n\nGauff, who sat out Gauff said she heard the out call, slowed down and hit the ball into the net.\n\nRather than replaying the point, as Gauff wanted, the chair awarded the point to Vekic, a budding star from Croatia. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at her debut Games -- in singles, doubles and mixed doubles, where her partner is Taylor Fritz. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from each event.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Games.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I'm just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. Last month, in that same stadium, Gauff was entangled in a heated dispute over a call after being beaten by eventual champion Iga Swiatek.\n\nDuring the exchange, Gauff walked over to the chair umpire in an argument that caused the match to be delayed for several minutes.\n\nGauff spoke about that eerily similar feeling after her match.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit, and I don't think the ref disagreed,\" she said. \"I think he just thought it didn't affect my swing, which I felt like it did.\"", {"uri": "8250943995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:44:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/sports/tearful-gauff-calls-for-video-replays-after-s-1848625.html", "title": "Tearful Gauff Calls For Video Replays After Stormy Olympic Exit - UrduPoint", "body": "Coco Gauff demanded the introduction of video replays at Roland Garros after being dumped out of the Olympic Games singles tennis tournament on Tuesday in a stormy defeat to impressive Donna Vekic of Croatia\n\nParis, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 30th Jul, 2024) Coco Gauff demanded the introduction of video replays at Roland Garros after being dumped out of the Olympic Games singles tennis tournament on Tuesday in a stormy defeat to impressive Donna Vekic of Croatia.\n\nVekic came through 7-6 (9/7), 6-2 to reach the quarter-finals after world number two Gauff became embroiled in a tearful, bitter dispute with the chair umpire over a line call in the sixth game of the second set.\n\nGauff, who had already surrendered a 5-2 lead in the first set, lost her composure on break point when a ball from Vekic was called out.\n\nHowever, Gauff then hit the return into the net as the chair umpire Jaume Campistol was correcting the original call.\n\nHe insisted the call had not hindered the American's shot.\n\nThe 20-year-old wept as she pleaded her case but the point and break was awarded to Vekic.\n\nGauff then called for the introduction of video replays to adjudicate controversial calls.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR (video review) system because these points are big deals. And, yeah, usually afterwards, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\n\n\"\n\nGauff added: \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nThe American star had also argued with the chair umpire during her semi-final loss to Iga Swiatek at the French Open last month.\n\nAgain, the dispute centred on a line call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" Gauff, who played a starring role at the Games opening ceremony on Friday where she carried the US flag with basketball superstar LeBron James, told the umpire on Tuesday.\n\n\"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nVekic, the first Croatian woman in the Olympic singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996, said the controversial incident was a \"very tricky situation\".\n\n\"I personally thought the umpire made a good decision because the call came quite late,\" said the 28-year-old Wimbledon semi-finalist.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the incident, Vekic had to save three break points in the seventh game as her momentum was checked by the delay.\n\n\"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in {"uri": "2024-07-438469538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:07:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:07:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:48:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tearful-gauff-calls-for-video-replays-after-stormy-olympic-exit/article_0ab1efa3-4e70-536a-b392-9dc82b85a0f5.html", "title": "Tearful Gauff calls for video replays after stormy Olympic exit", "body": "Coco Gauff demanded the introduction of video replays at Roland Garros after being dumped out of the Olympic Games singles tennis tournament on Tuesday in a stormy defeat to impressive Donna Vekic of Croatia.\n\nVekic came through 7-6 (9/7), 6-2 to reach the quarter-finals after world number two Gauff became embroiled in a tearful, bitter dispute with the chair umpire over a line call in the sixth game of the second set.\n\nGauff, who had already surrendered a 5-2 lead in the first set, lost her composure on break point when a ball from Vekic was called out.\n\nHowever, Gauff then hit the return into the net as the chair umpire Jaume Campistol was correcting the original call.\n\nHe insisted the call had not hindered the American's shot.\n\nThe 20-year-old wept as she pleaded her case but the point and break was awarded to Vekic.\n\nGauff then called for the introduction of video replays to adjudicate controversial calls.\n\nThe French Open venue is the only one of the four Grand Slams that does not utilise technology in any form as officials believe electronic aids are not accurate on dusty clay courts.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me,\" Gauff, a runner-up at the French Open on the same Court Philipper Chatrier in Paris in 2022.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR (video review) system because these points are big deals. And, yeah, usually afterwards, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff added: \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nThe American star had also argued with the chair umpire during her semi-final loss to Iga Swiatek at the French Open last month.\n\nAgain, the dispute centred on a line call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" Gauff, who played a starring role at the Games opening ceremony on Friday where she carried the US flag with basketball superstar LeBron James, told the umpire on Tuesday.\n\n\"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nVekic, the first Croatian woman in the Olympic singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996, said the controversial incident was a \"very tricky situation\".\n\n\"I personally thought the umpire made a good decision because the call came quite late,\" said the 28-year-old Wimbledon semi-finalist.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the incident, Vekic had to save three break points in the seventh game as her momentum was checked by the delay.\n\n\"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in that game because it was an important game,\" she said.\n\nVekic will face either Marta Kostyuk or Ukraine of Greece's Maria Sakkari for a place in the semi-finals.\n\nGauff, who sat out the delayed Tokyo Olympics with Covid, still has a chance of gold in Paris as she remains in both the women's and mixed doubles.\n\ndj/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nFix Support Apple Com/iPhone/Restore in 5 So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning US Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournaments?\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can't.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and women's doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nHer match was played at Court Suzanne Lenglen at the same time that, across the way at Court Philippe Chatrier, Novak Djokovic was A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead.\n\nShe then walked over to talk to the official, and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nGauff, a 20-year-old from Florida, was seeded second in Paris and easily won her first two singles matches, dropping a total of just five games.\n\nBut her first Olympic singles tournament - she is still in women's doubles and mixed doubles - ended with a performance that was hardly her best on the hottest day of the Summer Games so far, with the heat rising above 32 degrees celsius.\n\nEven before the trouble over the umpiring decision, Gauff could not sustain a good start against Vekic, who was a semifinalist at Wimbledon this month. Gauff took a one-set lead after holding to love as she served for the opening frame.\n\nGauff won the final eight games of the match, coasting through the second set with no problems. In winning the match, Gauff broke Tomljanovic's serve six times and sounded a warning to all who will face her in Paris.\n\nGauff's next opponent in the second round will be Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina, who defeated Tatjana Maria of Germany 6-0, 6-0 on Sunday in a great start to her Olympics.\n\nAlthough Gauff and Carle have never faced off in a senior professional setting, the American defeated Carle twiice in their junior careers, winning at the 2017 Junior US Open and the 2018 Wimbledon Girls championship.\n\nNaomi Osaka makes honest confession after early Paris 2024 exit\n\nParis 2024 Olympics suffers latest withdrawal blow as 5th seed pulls out\n\nGauff penned an emotional letter to her 17-year-old self who missed out on the Olympics for NBC ahead of the Games where she also laid out how proud she was to represent her country at the games.\n\n\"As you lean into your joy, keep being vocal about the causes you care about, just like grandma has done throughout her life,\" Gauff wrote.\"\n\n\"Your outlook isn't defined by the lines painted on the court; it's solidified by your convictions, your choice to support others and the belief that you can elicit change. Stay strong in who you are, and what you want to communicate with the world.\n\n\"In those times that the world doubts you - of which there will be plenty - don't let it frustrate you, let it fuel you. No one can dim your light as long you believe in it. As you hoist that silver trophy at the U.S. Open, your fire will never be brighter. Let it illuminate your future.\n\n\"It's always been an honour to represent the United States. As a member of the U.S. Billie Jean King Cup team, you will rally for the red, white and blue throughout your career, a distinct privilege you will enjoy.\n\n\"While tennis is an individual sport, you relish the relationships with your teammates. You've been lucky enough that your on-court relationships have turned into off-court friendships. One of those notable friendships is with your idol, Serena Williams.\n\n\"Serena was once just a stranger printed on a poster hanging in your room, and now you still can't believe she's a friend and mentor. {"uri": "8251130323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:03:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:03:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:02:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://fanbuzz.com/olympics/coco-gauff-in-tears-after-argument-with-umpire-over-controversial-call-leading-to-olympic-exit/", "title": "Coco Gauff In Tears Arguing With Umpire Over Controversial Call Leading To Olympic Exit", "body": "Team USA flag bearer Coco Gauff, the No. 2 ranked women's tennis player in the world, was upset by Donna Vekic in a shocking loss [7-6 (9-7), 6-2], which eliminated her from the singles competition at the Paris Olympics. That is to say, during the third round defeat, there was an intense argument with the chair umpire, which some believe affected the outcome.\n\nTo note, when the score was 30-30 in the second set, during a crucial point, Gauff served the ball to the Croatian player, who returned a shot which landed out of bounds according to the line judge. However, the chair judge has the final say, and he had a different ruling, saying the ball was in.\n\nTo clarify, Gauff wasn't saying the call was right/wrong by the line judge, but rather making the point that umpire's ruling by saying \"out\" when she was in the process of swinging led her to not finishing her shot, meaning that the point should be replayed.\n\nThat is to say, this led to a back-and-forth between Gauff and the chair umpire, Jaume Campistol.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff was heard saying to Campistol.\n\nThe 20-year-old was seen breaking down in tears over the matter during the match, as even the judge said \"maybe I was wrong.\"\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me, where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff told reporters afterward.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR (Video Assistant Referee) system because these points are big deals,\" Gauff continuted. \"Usually, afterwards they apologize... It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nAlthough it was just one point, in tennis every point matters and can shift the momentum to one player's way. In this case, Gauff went down 4-2 after this in a deciding third round.\n\n\"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point. But being down a break... Maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game... But I'm not gonna sit here and say one point affected the result today, because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened.\"\n\nAll in all, there has been much criticism for the umpires, but what almost everyone can agree on is that tennis needs a video review system, so this type of thing doesn't happen on the biggest stage.\n\nAfter the upset win, Veki? will now move on to her quarterfinal matchup which will take place Wednesday, July 31st.", "source": {"uri": "fanbuzz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FanBuzz - Sports News - NFL | NCAA | NBA |  WWE"}, Coco Gauff experienced it first-hand during her third-round game against Donna Vekic in the Olympics.\n\nDuring the match, the umpire called a ball out before Gauff could return the ball. That caused the American to miss her shot. However, Gauff believed that the ball was in and that the missed call interfered with her attempt.\n\nGauff pleaded her case to the umpire, but to no avail. At one point, the American was heard saying, \"It always happens to me on this court,\" clearly frustrated with the umpire's decision.\n\nGauff was already having a tough match against Vekic, as the Serbian was dominating the American star. Just when Gauff felt like she could make a run, she was saddled by this incident. Her frustration at the moment is quite understandable.\n\nFans sympathized with Gauff and echoed their frustration at the umpire's costly decision.\n\nGauff's frustration eventually led to her being eliminated after two sets. Regardless, the American star still had a historic event. She was the flag-bearer for Team USA and made it to the third round in her first Olympics.\n\nHopefully, this will be a learning lesson for the young star. She's only 20 years old playing in a high-pressure tournament. So what if she only put 55% of her first serves in play? So what if she wound up with six double-faults and zero aces?\n\nSo what if it took nearly 1 1/2 hours for the reigning U.S. Open champion and No. 2-ranked Gauff to finish off an opponent who is ranked 85th, has never won a tour-level singles title and owns an 0-2 career record at Grand Slam tournament?\n\n\"You can\u00b4t argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" the 20-year-old American said.\n\nSure can\u00b4t.\n\nLook at what she's managed to do so far at her first Olympics: Not only is Gauff 3-0 across singles and doubles, where her partner is Jessica Pegula, but she has dropped a combined total of only nine games across six sets in those three matches.\n\nCoco Gauff of the United States returns the ball against Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina during the women's singles tennis competition at the Roland Garros Stadium at the 2024 Summer Olympics on Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez)\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said about the matchup with Carle, someone she was familiar with from their days as junior players. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nGauff is hoping to win three medals at her debut Games - in singles, doubles and mixed doubles, where her partner is Taylor Fritz. Since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, no player has ever left a single Games with medals from each event.\n\nOn Monday, Gauff was not at all concerned by the heat, which rose into the 80s Fahrenheit for the first time during the Paris Games.\n\nBeing from Florida means that sort of thing is not a big deal, although she made some concessions, wearing ice-filled towels to cool off during changeovers and taking an ice bath after the match.\n\n\"I\u00b4m just trying my best to be preventative before maybe I feel fatigue and everything,\" Gauff said. \"Obviously, my last two matches, I went quick. So I\u00b4m just trying to think for the future, towards the end of the tournament.\"\n\nAP National Writer Jenna Fryer contributed.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nCoco Gauff of United States returns the ball against Maria Lourdes Carle of Argentina during the women's singles tennis competition at the at the Roland Garros stadium, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. Download for award-winning coverage, crosswords, audio storytelling, the eNewspaper and more.\n\nDown 7-6, 3-2 in a match that was tightly contested all the way through, Gauff faced a massive break point at 30-40. As she retreated to hit a backhand, the linesperson made an out call before Gauff swung her racket and she immediately decelerated, causing a miss.\n\nBut the chair umpire saw it differently, overruling the out call and awarding the point to Vekic.\n\nA five-minute argument ensued in which Gauff called the tournament supervisor and appeared to be crying, while saying, \"I feel like I'm getting cheated constantly in this game.\"\n\nWhen the match ensued, Gauff had an opportunity to get it back on serve in the next game, getting to 0-40 on Vekic's serve. But Vekic managed to reel in the break points and stretch out to a 5-2 lead. {"uri": "8250967665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:01:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:01:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:00:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://talksport.com/olympics/1988436/coco-gauff-major-rule-change-var-paris-2024-olympics/", "title": "Coco Gauff calls for major rule change after row with umpire at the Olympics", "body": "Coco Gauff has called for tennis to implement VAR after seeing her hopes of Olympic gold dashed in the women's singles.\n\nThe American superstar was facing Croatia's Donna Vekic in the third round at Roland Garros when she let her frustration over one key decision be known in her 7-6 (9-7) 6-2 defeat.\n\nDuring the contest, the 20-year-old American hit a serve and watched Vekic's return land near the baseline.\n\nAfter a line judge called the return out, Gauff didn't keep the ball in play.\n\nBut chair umpire Jaume Campistol believed that Vekic's return had safely landed in, and instead awarded the Croatian the point.\n\nClearly infuriated by the decision, Gauff had tears in her eyes and called for a change to the rules in her post-match interview.\n\nIt's not the first time that the 22-year-old has been left visibly angry at Roland Garros, with a similar incident occurring against Iga Swiatek at the French Open this year.\n\nAs a result, Gauff is keen for change.\n\nSpeaking to NBC after the match, Gauff said: \"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR system because these points are big deals.\n\n\"Usually, afterwards they apologise.\n\n\"It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff's frustration was clear to see on the court as she engaged in a lengthy dispute with Campistol.\n\nAccording to Eurosport, she said: \"This isn't fair, you called it out before I hit the ball. It's not fair... he called it out before I hit the ball.\n\n\"He called it out before I hit it, it affects the swing. I was going back to hit the ball, and he called it out before I hit it.\n\n\"You have to be 100 per cent sure. You're not, you just said maybe I'm wrong.\"\n\nGauff then added: \"It always happens here, every time.\n\n\"You don't understand. I have to always advocate for myself on this court! And, yeah, usually afterwards, they apologise, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff added: \"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nMore from this section PA: Governor Josh Shapiro Speaks at Pride Festival of Central Pennsylvania - 54816400 Notorious UK Islamist preacher jailed for life Delhi Rajender Nagar Coaching Flood Kills 3 | Mayor Shelly Oberoi Calls for Strict Action | Watch\n\nThe American star had also argued with the chair umpire during her semi-final loss to Iga Swiatek at the French Open last month.\n\nAgain, the dispute centred on a line call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" Gauff, who played a starring role at the Games opening ceremony on Friday where she carried the US flag with basketball superstar LeBron James, told the umpire on Tuesday.\n\n\"I'm getting cheated in this game. situation\".\n\n\"I personally thought the umpire made a good decision because the call came quite late,\" said the 28-year-old Wimbledon semi-finalist.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the incident, Vekic had to save three break points in the seventh game as her momentum was checked by the delay.\n\n\"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in that game because it was an important game,\" she said.\n\nVekic will face either Marta Kostyuk or Ukraine of Greece's Maria Sakkari for a place in the semi-finals.\n\nGauff, who sat out the delayed {"uri": "2024-07-438326675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:05:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:05:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:02:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.fresnobee.com/sports/olympics/article290565529.html", "title": "Coco Gauff Brought to Tears During Emotional Argument With Umpire After Brutal Call", "body": "Coco Gauff was left in tears during her third-round singles loss to Croatia's Donna Vekic in the Paris Olympics on Tuesday due to a brutal call from the umpire.\n\nDuring a break point in the second set, Vekic returned Gauff's serve, and the Croatian's shot landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called the shot out of bounds, but it was actually in. However, because of the \"out\" call, Gauff did not keep the ball in play and hit it into the net afterward. The chair umpire, Jaume Campistol, awarded Vekic the point because he believed the \"out\" call shouldn't have affected Gauff's swing.\n\nGauff was visibly upset and could be seen pleading her case to the umpire to the extent that the reigning U.S. Open champion was ultimately brought to tears over the unfair ruling.\n\n\"He called it out before I hit it so I went up on the ball,\" Gauff could be heard telling the ump on the broadcast. \"This isn't fair, he called it out before I hit the ball... If he called it out before I hit it, it affects the swing.\"\n\n\"I know I'm wrong, but I cannot change my decision after your appeal,\" the ump told Gauff at one point.\n\n\"I never argue these calls,\" Gauff said through tears. \"You don't understand, I have to always advocate for myself on this court all the time.\"\n\nA referee was then brought onto the court to mediate the dispute.\n\n\"This isn't fair,\" Gauff continued. \"I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game. And then you guys apologize afterwards, you guys say, 'I'm sorry,' but what does that do for me in the match?...It happens to me, it happens to Serena [Williams]... You guys are not fair to me. I hope that one day the game becomes fair, but it's not.\"\n\nVekic took a 4-2 lead after the minutes-long heated debate and ended up winning the match, 7-6 (7), 6-2.\n\nThis article was originally {"uri": "2024-07-437593805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "21:55:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T21:55:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T21:21:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-coco-gauff-aggressive-approach-round-2-win-maria-lourdes-carle", "title": "Coco Gauff's 'aggressive' approach to Olympic round 2 win over Maria Lourdes Carle", "body": "Coco Gauff has dropped nine games in three matches at Paris Olympics.\n\nReigning U.S. Open champion and current tennis World No. 2 Coco Gauff continued her impressive run at the Paris Olympics with a decisive 6-1, 6-1 victory over Argentina's Maria Lourdes Carle in the second round of singles on Monday. Despite facing some challenges, including a higher number of unforced errors and a lower first-serve percentage, Gauff's aggressive strategy carried her through.\n\n\"I knew that she was just going to probably try to out-rally me, which I feel like is one of my strengths. But also I had the ability to be aggressive,\" Gauff said of her matchup with Carle, via ESPN News Services. The two players are familiar with each other from their junior days, which added an extra layer of strategy to the match. \"So I think I was just trying to balance the mistakes and not let her win a lot of points off my racket.\"\n\nGauff's win was marked by double the unforced errors (26) compared to winners (11), only landing 55% of her first serves, and finishing with six double faults and no aces. Gauff struggled to complete her match in nearly 1.5 hours against an opponent ranked 85th, who has never won a tour-level singles title and has a 0-2 career record in Grand Slam tournaments.\n\n\"You can't argue with the scoreline, to be honest,\" Gauff said.\n\nCoco Gauff soaking in first Olympic experience\n\nThe 20-year-old American's performance at her first Olympics has been notable. It's her first Olympic games after she had to drop out of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics after testing positive for COVID-19 on the eve of the games. She is 3-0 in Paris in both singles and women's doubles, where she partners with Jessica Pegula. Across these matches, Gauff has dropped only nine games in six sets.\n\nThe match against Carle took place on Court Suzanne Lenglen simultaneously with a high-profile clash between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal on Court Philippe Chatrier. Gauff expressed a bit of disappointment at missing the opportunity to watch two of her sport's icons compete but appreciated the attendees at her match.\n\n\"Even at 6-1, 5-1, the crowd was still very much into the match, which normally isn't the case in most tournaments,\" she said, as reported by Peggy Shinn of Team USA. \"Everybody's trying to root for their player hard.\n\n\"Obviously, it'll suck if you lose, but I feel like there's a sense of pride, especially me being a first-time Olympian. It's one of the things I wanted to check off my list.
