{"uri": "8250726848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:23:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/?p=168181", "title": "Coco Gauff line call controversy at Paris 2024 shows tennis must make major change", "body": "\"This is not fair. You guys are not fair to me. I hope that one day the game becomes fair, but it's not.\"\n\nThose were the words of Coco Gauff - world No 2 and reigning US Open champion - after being dragged into a latest contentious line call controversy on Court Philippe Chatrier this summer.\n\nIn her Olympic women's singles round three tie on Tuesday, the second seed was at a crucial juncture of her match against Donna Vekic - down a set, and facing break point.\n\nThe Croatian hit a shot that was called long and in response, Gauff sprayed a groundstroke out of court - but the decision was overturned by umpire Jaume Campistol - and with that went a break of serve\n\nGauff was left incensed on the court, claiming the line call came before she hit her shot and debating heavily with Campistol and the tournament supervisor, ultimately to no avail.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But he called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff protested.\n\n\"It's not even a perception; it's the rules. I always have to advocate for myself.\"\n\nThe US star never seemingly recovered from the incident and, despite holding three break points when play resumed, fell away in a 7-6(7), 6-2 triumph for her opponent.\n\nDebate has raged since about whether Gauff or Campistol was right - but that misses the point.\n\nUltimately, it doesn't matter who was right or wrong in this situation; either way, it was difficult to watch - and is something that should be entirely avoidable.\n\nTennis was ahead of the curve when it came to sports using technology, implementing hawkeye well before football introduced VAR or goal-line technology.\n\nSome events now use automatic line calling and that will become commonplace, but it is not always an option on clay.\n\nThe ex-tennis power couple targeting Paris 2024 gold - despite recent split\n\nRafael Nadal explains why he opted against following Novak Djokovic's Olympic village decision\n\nIn any event still reliant on calls from line judges or the umpire, there should be a video replay system available for umpires and players to double-check decisions such as this.\n\nThousands of fans watching this contest across all corners of the globe could see the replay of the incident, making it baffling that Gauff, Campistol and Vekic were unable to do so.\n\nThe replay suggests Gauff may have been wrong, and being able to see that clearly would have brought more clarity to the situation and could well have ended the debacle that ensued.\n\nIt is pretty immaterial whether she was wrong or right, though, as there is evident distrust from her and other players in similar situations.\n\nThe American was certainly in the right on the very same court during a similar situation in her French Open semi-final against Iga Swiatek back in June.\n\nGauff was again left in tears after a contentious call from Aurelie Tourte that day, and she is by far from the only player caught up in such a controversy.\n\nAlmost every player on the WTA and ATP has been caught up in a controversy such as this at one point in their career - which is not acceptable on any level.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR system because these points are big deals,\" said Gauff after the match.\n\n\"Usually, afterwards they apologize. It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nShe is correct, and it is beyond belief that tennis officials have not yet come to the same conclusion.", Vekic trailed 4-1 and 5-3 in the opening set, saving a set point on serve there, and later erased two chances for Gauff in the tiebreak to earn her second Top 10 win of the season and 14th of her career.\n\nVekic also earned a win over a player ranked in the world's Top 3 at the last Olympics, having defeated then-No.3 Aryna Sabakenka in Tokyo, but her win over Gauff marked a milestone: All of her previous Top 10 wins came on either hard courts or grass.\n\nHer win also matches the best-ever result for a Croatian woman at the Olympics, as Iva Majoli made the quarterfinals in 1996.\n\nKerber's farewell continues, into Paris Olympic quarterfinals\n\nAfter a tight opening set that lasted more than an hour, Gauff was the first player to break serve in the second set, but ultimately lost the last five games. Vekic's second service break came in controversial fashion. At 30-40, she hit a return deep to Gauff's forehand, which the American mishit into the net. The shot was called out by the line umpire, who then immediately corrected the original call, and the point was awarded to Vekic.\n\nThe decision visibly upset Gauff, who nonetheless led 0-40 in the Croatian's subsequent service game. But Vekic escaped with a hold -- a drop shot winner and a lob winner helping the baseliner's cause -- as she won 10 of the last 12 points of the match.\n\nIn all, Vekic struck 28 winners to Gauff's {"uri": "8250822956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:24:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:24:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:23:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/paris-olympics-tennis-coco-gauff-loses-to-vekic-in-singles/20240730.htm", "title": "Olympics Tennis: Gauff loses to Vekic in singles", "body": "IMAGE: Coco Gauff in action during the women's singles third round match against Croatia's Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympic Games on Tuesday. Photograph: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports/Reuters\n\nAmerican Coco Gauff's hopes of singles gold at the Olympics evaporated in the third round as she argued with officials and slumped to a 7-6(7), 6-2 defeat by Croatia's Donna Vekic in furnace-like conditions at Roland Garros in Paris on Tuesday.\n\nThe 20-year-old second seed marched into a 5-2 lead in the opening set but Vekic responded with some sublime claycourt tennis to turn the match on its head.\n\nVekic saved two set points in a crucial opening set tiebreak and was the better player as she became the first Croatian to reach the Olympic women's singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996.\n\nUS Open champion Gauff was left angry and in tears as an over-ruled line call saw her slip 4-2 down in the second set, the American being overheard saying \"I'm being cheated.\"\n\nHer long protestations with the umpire and supervisor came to nothing though.\n\nThe sun-baked Philippe Chatrier crowd got behind Gauff after that but ice-cool Vekic, seeded 13th, sealed the win as the American's game disintegrated. Olympic debutant Gauff will now focus on mixed doubles and women's doubles.\n\nIMAGE: Donna Vekic is the first Croatian to reach the Olympic women's singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996. Photograph: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports/Reuters\n\nGauff refused to blame the dispute for her loss but insisted, with some justification, that the point should have been replayed because the line judge's initial shout of \"out\" impeded her stroke.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit and I don't think the referee disagreed but he just thought it didn't affect my swing which I felt like it did,\" she told reporters.\n\n\"I mean, there's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis we should have a VR (video review) because these points are big deals. Afterwards they apologise, but sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\n\n\"But I'm not going to sit here and say one point effected the result today, I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nIMAGE: Coco Gauff congratulates Donna Vekic after the match. Photograph: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports/Reuters\n\nThe 28-year-old Vekic suffered a heart-breaking loss to Jasmine Paolini in the Wimbledon semi-finals but has bounced back impressively in Paris.\n\nShe said the atmosphere on the court was one of the best she had played in.\n\n\"It was very, very tough. When we practised this morning the roof was closed so it took me a couple of games to adjust (to the heat). The ball was flying a little bit,\" she said.\n\n\"The support has been unbelievable and I'm having a great time in the village so hopefully I can win one or two matches more. {"uri": "8250657070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:42:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:42:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:41:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/tennis/coco-gauff-paris-olympics-vekic-33358184", "title": "Coco Gauff in tears during heated argument with umpire at Olympic Games", "body": "US tennis star Coco Gauff was left in tears as she argued with the umpire during her second round match against Donna Vekic at the Olympics\n\nCoco Gauff broke down in tears at the Olympics as a row with the umpire and supervisor overshadowed her defeat to Donna Vekic.\n\nThe world No.2 lost the first set on a tiebreak against Vekic and was broken in the second after a controversial moment. Trailing 2-3 in the second set and facing break point, Vekic's shot was initially called out mid-rally. It was immediately self-corrected and Gauff sent the ball into the net, with the point awarded to the world No. 21.\n\nThe American argued she was affected by an incorrect call and stormed to the umpire's chair.\n\n\"For me, the call didn't affect your shot,\" he responded. But a furious Gauff retorted: \"He called it out before I hit it. That's why I went up on the ball.\"\n\nThe 20 year-old continued to argue her point and the supervisor was called to the court. Commentator Miles Maclagan said: \"I think the umpire has made the correct call. I have sympathy for both because it happened so quickly and you're not necessarily looking for it either,\"\n\nSupervisor Clare Wood arrived and Gauff turned her attention to her: \"You have to understand, he called it out before I hit it,\" she continued.\n\n\"What's the rule? It's not even a millisecond, he called it when I hit the ball. I understand if it was the same time but it was before. It's not even a perception.\n\n\"I always have to advocate for myself. It happened to me in July, it happened to me here. This isn't fair. This isn't fair. I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game. I constantly feel like that and then I have to argue. No because I do and then you guys apologise after.\"\n\nAs Gauff vented her frustration, co-commentator Naomi Cavaday chimed in: \"Clare Wood just telling her to be careful here with the language she's using. Vekic is waiting. We don't have video review for the players to use for this. It is a judgement call.\n\n\"If Gauff had hit the ball into the court it would be a replay but because she missed the shot, the point has been awarded to her opponent because the call was wrong.\n\n\"Gauff's argument is that it impacted her shot and the call made her miss. When it happens on the baseline there is such little time between the bounce and your swing that the most likely situation is that the call has not impacted your swing because it's such a reaction, it's so quick, there's no time for it.\"\n\nThe atmosphere turned sour with boos echoing around Court Philippe-Chatrier as the match resumed, and Vekic was overheard reassuring the crowd: \"It's not Gauff argued her shot was compromised by the initial call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" said a weeping Gauff, 20. \"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nVekic, ranked 21, briefly lost her composure, slipping to 0-40 on her own serve before recovering to hold, and she broke again to seal victory.\n\n\"It took me some time to adjust to the conditions because when we warmed up the roof was closed so it was completely different when we came out there,\" she said.\n\n\"The ball was flying a little bit more so it took me a couple of games but after that I think I played pretty well and it was a really tough match.\"\n\nNext up on Philippe-Chatrier was defending men's champion Alexander Zverev, who was taking on 39th-ranked Czech Tomas Machac before women's world number one Iga Swiatek targets a 24th straight win on the clay courts of Paris.\n\nPoland's Swiatek, who has not lost at Roland Garros since 2021, takes on China's Wang Xiyu in the evening session.\n\n'Nadalacaraz'\n\nNadal, a 14-time French Open champion, was swept off court by old rival Novak Djokovic in straight sets in the pair's 60th meeting on Monday.\n\nThe 38-year-old, immortalised in a statue at Roland Garros, has been plagued by injuries in recent years and slumped to 161st in the world.\n\nThe former world number one said after his painful defeat to Djokovic that he would make a decision on his future after the Olympics.\n\nBut the Spaniard, who won singles gold at the 2008 Beijing Games and doubles gold in Rio in 2016, can still collect a medal in the doubles alongside current French Open and Wimbledon champion Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThey take on Dutch pair Tallon Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\nAnother player in the final chapter of a storied career is Britain's Andy Murray, who, like Nadal, has battled crippling injuries over the past few years, slumping to 117 in the world.\n\nThe British three-time Grand Slam champion pulled off an astonishing escape act with doubles partner Dan Evans in their opening match, saving five match points in the deciding tie-break against Kei Nishikori and Taro Gauff humorously noted in the caption, \"10 girls, two bathrooms. #olympicvillage.\"\n\nThe Olympic Village, designed to host 14,250 athletes, has faced criticism from some athletes. The tight quarters and limited facilities led many of Gauff's teammates to opt for hotel accommodations.\n\nIn response to a suggestion on social media that the athletes should move to a hotel, Gauff confirmed that all of the other tennis players had already done so, leaving just her and a few others in the Village.\n\nGauff also commented on the basic quality of the living conditions, including the \"anti-sex\" cardboard beds that have been widely discussed.\n\nTo improve her comfort, she borrowed a mattress topper from the US Archery team. {"uri": "8250800188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:14:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:14:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:09:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.arnnewscentre.ae/en/news/sports/gauffs-singles-hopes-melt-away-at-paris-olympics/", "title": "Gauff's singles hopes melt away at Paris Olympics", "body": "American Coco Gauff's hopes of singles gold at the Olympics evaporated in the third round as she argued with officials and slumped to a 7-6(7) 6-2 defeat by Croatia's Donna Vekic at Roland Garros on Tuesday.\n\nThe 20-year-old second seed marched into a 5-2 lead in the opening set but Vekic responded with some sublime claycourt tennis to turn the match on its head.\n\nVekic saved two set points in a crucial opening set tiebreak and was the better player as she became the first Croatian to reach the Olympic women's singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996.\n\nUS Open champion Gauff was left angry and in tears as an over-ruled line call saw her slip 4-2 down in the second set, the American being overheard saying \"I'm being cheated.\"\n\nHer long protestations with the umpire and supervisor came to nothing though.\n\nThe sun-baked Philippe Chatrier crowd got behind Gauff after that but ice-cool Vekic, seeded 13th, sealed the win as the American's game disintegrated. Olympic debutant Gauff will now focus on mixed doubles and women's doubles.\n\nGauff refused to blame the dispute for her loss but insisted, with some justification, that the point should have been replayed because the line judge's initial shout of \"out\" impeded her stroke.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit and I don't think the referee disagreed but he just thought it didn't affect my swing which I felt like it did,\" she told reporters.\n\n\"I mean, there's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis we should have a VR (video review) because these points are big deals. Afterwards they apologise, but sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\n\n\"But I'm not going to sit here and say one point effected the result today, I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nThe 28-year-old Vekic suffered a heart-breaking loss to Jasmine Paolini in the Wimbledon semi-finals but has bounced back impressively in Paris.\n\nShe said the atmosphere on the court was one of the best she had played in.\n\n\"It was very, very tough. When we practised this morning the roof was closed so it took me a couple of games to adjust (to the heat). The ball was flying a little bit,\" she said.\n\n\"The support has been unbelievable and I'm having a great time in the village so hopefully I can win one or two matches more. {"uri": "2024-07-438488625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:25:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:25:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:19:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/tennis/coco-gauff-crashes-out-of-paris-olympics-in-tears-after-heated-row-with-umpire-during-defeat-against-donna-vekic-101722352155408.html", "title": "Coco Gauff crashes out of Paris Olympics in tears after heated row with umpire during defeat against Donna Vekic", "body": "With temperatures rocketing into the mid-30s Celsius at Roland Garros, officials activated a heat protocol, allowing a 10-minute break between the second and third sets.\n\nIn the first match on Court Philippe-Chatrier, Vekic shocked Gauff 7-6 (9/7), 6-2 to reach the quarter-finals, but the match was overshadowed by a lengthy row between the US Open champion and the chair umpire.\n\nGauff, the flag-bearer for the United States at the Olympic opening ceremony alongside NBA star LeBron James, made a fast start but squandered three set points before her Croatian opponent won the first-set tie-break.\n\nThe pair swapped breaks early in the second set but the match came to a standstill at the end of the sixth game as an emotional Gauff pleaded her case with the umpire.\n\nAt 30-40, Vekic hit a return deep to Gauff's forehand, which the American mishit into the net.\n\nVekic's shot was called out but the call was overruled by the chair umpire and the point was awarded to the Croat, giving her the break. Gauff argued her shot was compromised by the initial call.\n\n\"I have to advocate for myself all the time,\" a weeping Gauff, 20, said on court. \"I'm getting cheated in this game. You guys are not fair to me.\"\n\nLater, a more composed Gauff called for a video review system at Roland Garros to match those in place at other Grand Slam venues.\n\n\"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point but, for sure, being not a break, whereas maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game,\" she said.\n\nVekic, ranked 21, briefly lost her composure, slipping to 0-40 on her own serve before recovering to hold, and she broke again to seal victory.\n\nThe Wimbledon semi-finalist said the row over the line call was a \"tricky situation\".\n\n\"After that, the crowd, it was not so easy,\" she said. \"I lost my concentration for a couple of points, but I'm happy that I managed to come back in that game because it was an important game.\"\n\nGermany's defending men's champion Alexander Zverev coasted into the third round with a 6-3, 7-5 win over 39th-ranked Czech Tomas Machac.\n\nIn the women's draw, three-time Grand Slam champion Angelique Kerber of Germany progressed to the quarter-finals along with US eighth seed Danielle Collins and China's Zheng Qinwen.\n\nWomen's world number one Iga Swiatek targets a 24th straight win on the clay courts of Paris against China's Wang Xiyu in the evening session.\n\nNadal, a 14-time French Open champion, was swept off court by old rival Novak Djokovic in straight sets in the pair's 60th meeting on Monday.\n\nThe 38-year-old, immortalised in a statue at Roland Garros, has been plagued by injuries in recent years and is now 161st in the world.\n\nNadal said after his painful defeat to Djokovic that he would make a decision on his future after the Olympics.\n\nBut the Spaniard, who won singles gold at the 2008 Beijing Games and doubles gold in Rio in 2016, can still collect a medal in the doubles alongside current French Open and Wimbledon champion Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThey take on Dutch pair Tallon Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof.\n\nBritain's three-time Grand {"uri": "8251060798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:08:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:08:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:07:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/vekic-upsets-gauff-in-olympic-tennis-event/", "title": "Vekic Upsets Gauff In Olympic Tennis Event", "body": "July 30, (THEWILL) - American tennis star Coco Gauff's quest for Olympic singles gold came to an abrupt halt on Tuesday at Roland Garros. The 20-year-old second seed lost to Croatia's Donna Vekic in the third round, with a final score of 7-6(7) 6-2.\n\nGauff started strong, leading 5-2 in the first set. However, 28-year-old Vekic mounted an impressive comeback, winning the tiebreak and dominating the second set. The match was played in extremely hot conditions, which added to the challenge for both players.\n\nTension picked up in the second set when Gauff disputed a line call that put her 4-2 down. The American player's protests to the umpire and supervisor were unsuccessful, and she was heard saying: \"I'm being cheated.\" Despite support from the crowd, Gauff could not regain her composure, and her game faltered.\n\nVekic's victory marks a significant achievement for Croatian tennis, as she becomes the first player from her country to reach the Olympic women's singles quarter-finals since Iva Majoli in 1996. The 13th seed will now look to continue her strong form in the next round.\n\nWhile Gauff's singles campaign has ended, she will now focus on the mixed doubles and women's doubles events. Vekic trailed 4-1 and 5-3 in the opening set, saving a set point on serve there, and later erased two chances for Gauff in the tiebreak to earn her second Top 10 win of the season and 14th of her career.\n\nVekic also earned a win over a player ranked in the world's Top 3 at the last Olympics, having defeated then-No.3 Aryna Sabakenka in Tokyo, but her win over Gauff marked a milestone: All of her previous Top 10 wins came on either hard courts or grass.\n\nAfter a tight opening set that lasted more than an hour, Gauff was the first player to break serve in the second set, but ultimately lost the last five games. Vekic's second service break came in controversial fashion. At 30-40, she hit a return deep to Gauff's forehand, which the American mishit into the net. The shot was called out by the line umpire, who then immediately corrected the original call, and the point was awarded to Vekic.\n\nThe decision visibly upset Gauff, who nonetheless led 0-40 in the Croatian's subsequent service game. Olympic debutant Gauff will now focus on mixed doubles and women's doubles.\n\nGauff refused to blame the dispute for her loss but insisted, with some justification, that the point should have been replayed because the line judge's initial shout of \"out\" impeded her stroke.\n\n\"I felt that he called it before I hit and I don't think the referee disagreed but he just thought it didn't affect my swing which I felt like it did,\" she told reporters.\n\n\"I mean, there's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court.\n\n\"I feel like in tennis we should have a VR (video review) because these points are big deals. Afterwards they apologise, but sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\n\n\"But I'm not going to sit here and say one point effected the result today, I was already on the losing side of things.\"\n\nThe 28-year-old Vekic suffered a heart-breaking loss to Jasmine Paolini in the Wimbledon semi-finals but has bounced back impressively in Paris.\n\nShe said the atmosphere on the court was one of the best she had played in.\n\n\"It was very, very tough. When we practised this morning the roof was closed so it took me a couple of games to adjust (to the heat). "body": "Tennis should introduce \"incidental replays\" with renowned coach Brad Gilbert saying the sport needs to change following the latest line controversy involving Coco Gauff at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nReigning US Open champion Gauff's singles participation at the 2024 Games at Roland Garros came to a dramatic end in the third round as she lost 7-6 (9-7), 6-2 against Donna Vekic of Croatia.\n\nThere was drama midway through the second set with a call leaving the American furious.\n\nA Vekic return was initially called out by the linesperson with Gauff then hitting her return into the net, but the chair umpire then overruled the original call and the point was awarded to the Croatian.\n\nIt gave Vekic the crucial break and she went 4-2 up, but Gauff was upset and argued her case with the officials, but to no avail.\n\nTennis has been using Hawkeye for more than two decades, but it is only used for line calls and not for other controversial moments.\n\nGauff's coach Gilbert feels it is time for the sport to introduce replays across the board as he wrote on X: \"I have said since we introduced Hawkeye replay calls like 20 years ago, That we should absolutely have incidental replays, umpires should have a tv monitor to look at replay, same with tournament referee if they come to court, must see replay quickly.\"\n\nGauff first argued with the tournament officials as she felt victimised.\n\n\"I feel like I'm getting cheated on constantly in this game,\" she said at one point, adding \"it happens to me, it happened to Serena [Williams].\"\n\nDuring the post-match press conference, the American insisted that the call was made before she hit her return into the net and said that the sport should use a Video Assistant Referee [VAR].\n\n\"There have been multiple times this year where that happened to me where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court. I feel like in tennis, we should have a VAR (Video Assistant Referee) system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards they apologise,\" she said.\n\n\"It's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\n\n\"I can't say I would have won the match if I would have won that point. But being down a break... Maybe replaying that point can make a big difference in that game.\"\n\nCoco Gauff line call controversy at Paris 2024 shows tennis must make major change\n\nThe 5 youngest women to win Olympic singles gold - ft. {"uri": "2024-07-438472437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:10:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:10:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.wbaltv.com/article/coco-gauff-exit-2024-paris-olympics-singles-umpire-call/61739402", "title": "Tearful Coco Gauff exits Paris Olympics singles competition after controversial umpire call", "body": "Coco Gauff looked to be cruising against Donna Veki\u0107 in her third-round singles match at the Paris Olympics. Then, all of a sudden, she wasn't.Having been a point away from taking the first set at Roland Garros, Gauff had to watch the contest slip away from her, eventually succumbing to a 7-6(7) 6-2 upset defeat on Court Philippe-Chatrier.Related video above: The U.S. connection to France is hard to miss in ParisThe most fraught moment of the match came midway through the second set when Gauff was reduced to tears during a heated exchange with chair umpire Jaume Campistol.A line call on Gauff's baseline was initially deemed out, but Campistol overruled the decision and handed Veki\u0107 a crucial break point. Play was then paused as the American vehemently argued that the point should be replayed as the call was made just before she hit the ball.The supervisor also came onto the court and the ensuing debate lasted five minutes, with Gauff wiping tears away from her eyes. Boos and jeers came from the crowd when play was eventually resumed.\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" she later told reporters.\"And I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterward, they apologize, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"Gauff immediately created three break points the following game, but Veki\u0107 shut down the opening, saving the last point with an inch-perfect lob before taking a 4-2 lead in the second set.The match was firmly in the Croatian's control from that point, and she closed out the contest to set up a quarterfinal meeting with either Greece's Maria Sakkari or Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk.\"Donna played well,\" said Gauff. \"She's been playing well throughout Wimbledon 'til now, so I knew it would be a tough match. I think I had a lot of chances in the first, and I felt like if I could clinch that set, it might have helped me in the momentum of the second.\"The match was played in the baking midday sun with temperatures expected to reach 95 degrees Fahrenheit in Paris, though adding in the humidity, the heat index was 104 degrees F - easily the hottest day of the Olympics so far.On Court Philippe-Chatrier, sun hats and hand-held fans were out in force, and an automated stadium announcement between games reminded spectators to drink water and take regular breaks from the heat.Gauff collapseGauff, the world No. 2 and a strong pre-tournament contender to medal in the women's singles event, stormed into an early first-set lead, but after seeing a set point saved by Veki\u0107, she lost her break advantage when a forehand drifted wide.As the set wore on, Veki\u0107 played the shot of the match at that point, pushing a smash back past her opponent. But Gauff responded in similar fashion the following game, returning a Veki\u0107 smash with a well-timed backhand while her opponent was stranded at the net.Both players had set points in the tie-break, but it was Veki\u0107 who capitalized on the opportunity, raising her level when it mattered to take a one-set lead in more than an hour.Veki\u0107, a semifinalist at Wimbledon earlier this month, lost an early break with a double fault at the start of the second set, but she managed to take the next five games in a row and wrap up the victory in brutal conditions.\"It was very, very tough out there, the conditions, when we warmed up this morning and the roof was closed,\" Veki\u0107 told reporters. \"It took me a couple of games to adjust; it was very hot. The ball was flying a little bit, but after that, I got in rhythm and it was pretty good.\"The dispute with the umpire in the second set, Gauff later explained, didn't alter the result of the match.\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened,\" she said.The 20-year-old, a flag bearer for Team USA at the opening ceremony, still has mixed and women's doubles competitions to come in Paris having won her opening match in the latter alongside Jessica Pegula on Saturday.\n\nCoco Gauff looked to be cruising against Donna Veki\u0107 in her third-round singles match at the Paris Olympics. Then, all of a sudden, she wasn't.\n\nHaving been a point away from taking the first set at Roland Garros, Gauff had to watch the contest slip away from her, eventually succumbing to a 7-6(7) 6-2 upset defeat on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nRelated video above: The U.S. connection to France is hard to miss in Paris\n\nThe most fraught moment of the match came midway through the second set when Gauff was reduced to tears during a heated exchange with chair umpire Jaume Campistol.\n\nA line call on Gauff's baseline was initially deemed out, but Campistol overruled the decision and handed Veki\u0107 a crucial break point. Play was then paused as the American vehemently argued that the point should be replayed as the call was made just before she hit the ball.\n\nThe supervisor also came onto the court and the ensuing debate lasted five minutes, with Gauff wiping tears away from her eyes. Boos and jeers came from the crowd when play was eventually resumed.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" she later told reporters.\n\n\"And I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR [video review] system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterward, they apologize, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff immediately created three break points the following game, but Veki\u0107 shut down the opening, saving the last point with an inch-perfect lob before taking a 4-2 lead in the second set.\n\nThe match was firmly in the Croatian's control from that point, and she closed out the contest to set up a quarterfinal meeting with either Greece's Maria Sakkari or Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk.\n\n\"Donna played well,\" said Gauff. \"She's been playing well throughout Wimbledon 'til now, so I knew it would be a tough match. I think I had a lot of chances in the first, and I felt like if I could clinch that set, it might have helped me in the momentum of the second.\"\n\nThe match was played in the baking midday sun with temperatures expected to reach 95 degrees Fahrenheit in Paris, though adding in the humidity, the heat index was 104 degrees F - easily the hottest day of the Olympics so far.\n\nOn Court Philippe-Chatrier, sun hats and hand-held fans were out in force, and an automated stadium announcement between games reminded spectators to drink water and take regular breaks from the heat.\n\nGauff collapse\n\nGauff, the world No. 2 and a strong pre-tournament contender to medal in the women's singles event, stormed into an early first-set lead, but after seeing a set point saved by Veki\u0107, she lost her break advantage when a forehand drifted wide.\n\nAs the set wore on, Veki\u0107 played the shot of the match at that point, pushing a smash back past her opponent. But Gauff responded in similar fashion the following game, returning a Veki\u0107 smash with a well-timed backhand while her opponent was stranded at the net.\n\nBoth players had set points in the tie-break, but it was Veki\u0107 who capitalized on the opportunity, raising her level when it mattered to take a one-set lead in more than an hour.\n\nVeki\u0107, a semifinalist at Wimbledon earlier this month, lost an early break with a double fault at the start of the second set, but she managed to take the next five games in a row and wrap up the victory in brutal conditions.\n\n\"It was very, very tough out there, the conditions, when we warmed up this morning and the roof was closed,\" Veki\u0107 told reporters. \"It took me a couple of games to adjust; it was very hot. The ball was flying a little bit, but after that, I got in rhythm and it was pretty good.\"\n\nThe dispute with the umpire in the second set, Gauff later explained, didn't alter the result of the match.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened,\" she said.\n\nThe 20-year-old, a flag bearer for Team USA at the opening ceremony, still has mixed and women's doubles competitions to come in Paris having won her opening match in the latter alongside Jessica Pegula on Saturday.", {"uri": "2024-07-438424043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:22:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/30/sport/coco-gauff-paris-olympics-tennis-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Tearful Coco Gauff exits Paris Olympics singles competition after controversial line call", "body": "Coco Gauff reacts as a call goes against her at the Paris Olympics.\n\nCoco Gauff looked to be cruising against Donna Veki\u0107 in her third-round singles match at the Paris Olympics. Then, all of a sudden, she wasn't.\n\nHaving been a point away from taking the first set at Roland Garros, Gauff had to watch the contest slip away from her, eventually succumbing to a 7-6(7) 6-2 upset defeat on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nThe most fraught moment of the match came midway through the second set when Gauff was reduced to tears during a heated exchange with chair umpire Jaume Campistol.\n\nA line call on Gauff's baseline was initially deemed out, but Campistol overruled the decision and handed Veki\u0107 a crucial break point. Play was then paused as the American vehemently argued that the point should be replayed as the call was made just before she hit the ball.\n\nThe supervisor also came onto the court and the ensuing debate lasted five minutes, with Gauff wiping tears away from her eyes. Boos and jeers came from the crowd when play was eventually resumed.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" she later told reporters.\n\n\"And I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR [video review] system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards, they apologize, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff immediately created three break points the following game, but Veki\u0107 shut down the opening, saving the last point with an inch-perfect lob before taking a 4-2 lead in the second set.\n\nGauff argues with the supervisor during her defeat against Donna Veki\u0107.\n\nPatricia de Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images\n\nThe match was firmly in the Croatian's control from that point, and she closed out the contest to set up a quarterfinal meeting with either Greece's Maria Sakkari or Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk.\n\n\"Donna played well,\" said Gauff. \"She's been playing well throughout Wimbledon 'til now, so I knew it would be a tough match. I think I had a lot of chances in the first, and I felt like if I could clinch that set, it might have helped me in the momentum of the second.\"\n\nThe match was played in the baking midday sun with temperatures expected to reach 95 degrees Fahrenheit (35 degrees Celsius) in Paris, though adding in the humidity, the heat index was 104 degrees F (40 degrees C) - easily the hottest day of the Olympics so far.\n\nOn Court Philippe-Chatrier, sun hats and hand-held fans were out in force, and an automated stadium announcement between games reminded spectators to drink water and take regular breaks from the heat.\n\nGauff collapse\n\nGauff, the world No. 2 and a strong pre-tournament contender to medal in the women's singles event, stormed into an early first-set lead, but after seeing a set point saved by Veki\u0107, she lost her break advantage when a forehand drifted wide.\n\nAs the set wore on, Veki\u0107 played the shot of the match at that point, pushing a smash back past her opponent. But Gauff responded in similar fashion the following game, returning a Veki\u0107 smash with a well-timed backhand while her opponent was stranded at the net.\n\nBoth players had set points in the tie-break, but it was Veki\u0107 who capitalized on the opportunity, raising her level when it mattered to take a one-set lead in more than an hour.\n\nVeki\u0107, a semifinalist at Wimbledon earlier this month, lost an early break with a double fault at the start of the second set, but she managed to take the next five games in a row and wrap up the victory in brutal conditions.\n\n\"It was very, very tough out there, the conditions, when we warmed up this morning and the roof was closed,\" Veki\u0107 told reporters. \"It took me a couple of games to adjust; it was very hot. The ball was flying a little bit, but after that, I got in rhythm and it was pretty good.\"\n\nThe dispute with the umpire in the second set, Gauff later explained, didn't alter the result of the match.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened,\" she said.\n\nThe 20-year-old, a flag bearer for Team USA at the opening ceremony, still has mixed and women's doubles competitions to come in Paris having won her opening match in the latter alongside Jessica Pegula on Saturday.", That's why I went up on the ball,\" Gauff retorted.\n\nThere followed a a five-minute argument in which Gauff insisted that the tournament supervisor come to the court and, according to USA Today, So that's why I'm in the village,\" she says. \"Just rubbing toes and I'm really trying to take everything in and learn from all the athletes that I am around. I'm a rookie compared to most of them, so I have a lot to learn.\"\n\nAs for 100- and 200-meter sprinter Lyles' advice, Gauff says that he dropped \"pieces of wisdom.\"\n\n\"He's an interesting guy. So that's something I'll never forget.\"\n\nThat commingling of athletes is exactly why Gauff opted to stay at the Olympic Village, she tells PEOPLE.\n\n\"I mean, I had breakfast with Noah Lyles this morning, so hopefully some of his greatness can rub off of me. So that's why I'm in the village,\" she says. \"Just rubbing toes and I'm really trying to take everything in and learn from all the athletes that I am around. I'm a rookie compared to most of them, so I have a lot to learn.\"\n\nRelated: The Most Surprising Rules You Didn't Know Athletes Must Follow in the Olympic Village\n\nAs for 100- and 200-meter sprinter Lyles' advice, Gauff says that he dropped \"pieces of wisdom.\"\n\n\"He's an interesting guy. He's very confident, and I think I could learn to be more confident, too,\" she says.\n\nGauff, who had the honor of being Team USA's female flagbearer during the opening ceremony, says she's met a ton of her sports heroes in the village, including Biles, Sha'Carri Richardson, Suni Lee, Kelsey Plum and A'ja Wilson.\n\n\"When I have kids I'll be like, 'Yeah, I met all these people, they're like my best friends,' \" Gauff says dryly.\n\nOutside the village, Gauff has a stacked schedule -- she's competing in women's singles, women's doubles and mixed doubles, meaning she's playing multiple matches a day. But after missing out on the 2020 Tokyo Olympics due to testing positive for COVID the day she was supposed to leave, Gauff is soaking it all in.\n\n\"I just love winning, I love the vibes. {"uri": "8250835560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:32:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:32:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:31:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/tearful-coco-gauff-exits-paris-olympics-singles-competition-after-controversial-umpire-call/article_9abda88e-a341-549b-b272-4694e97eb93e.html", "title": "Tearful Coco Gauff exits Paris Olympics singles competition after controversial umpire call", "body": "Roland Garros, Paris (CNN) -- Coco Gauff looked to be cruising against Donna Veki\u0107 in her third-round singles match at the Paris Olympics. Then, all of a sudden, she wasn't.\n\nHaving been a point away from taking the first set at Roland Garros, Gauff had to watch the contest slip away from her, eventually succumbing to a 7-6(7) 6-2 upset defeat on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nThe most fraught moment of the match came midway through the second set when Gauff was reduced to tears during a heated exchange with chair umpire Jaume Campistol.\n\nA line call on Gauff's baseline was initially deemed out, but Campistol overruled the decision and handed Veki\u0107 a crucial break point. Play was then paused as the American vehemently argued that the point should be replayed as the call was made just before she hit the ball.\n\nThe supervisor also came onto the court and the ensuing debate lasted five minutes, with Gauff wiping tears away from her eyes. Boos and jeers came from the crowd when play was eventually resumed.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" she later told reporters.\n\n\"And I feel like in tennis, we should have a VR [video review] system because these points are big deals. Usually, afterwards, they apologize, so it's kind of frustrating when the sorry doesn't help you once the match is over.\"\n\nGauff immediately created three break points the following game, but Veki\u0107 shut down the opening, saving the last point with an inch-perfect lob before taking a 4-2 lead in the second set.\n\nThe match was firmly in the Croatian's control from that point, and she closed out the contest to set up a quarterfinal meeting with either Greece's Maria Sakkari or Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk.\n\n\"Donna played well,\" said Gauff. \"She's been playing well throughout Wimbledon 'til now, so I knew it would be a tough match. I think I had a lot of chances in the first, and I felt like if I could clinch that set, it might have helped me in the momentum of the second.\"\n\nThe match was played in the baking midday sun with temperatures expected to reach 95 degrees Fahrenheit (35 degrees Celsius) in Paris, though adding in the humidity, the heat index was 104 degrees F (40 degrees C) - easily the hottest day of the Olympics so far.\n\nOn Court Philippe-Chatrier, sun hats and hand-held fans were out in force, and an automated stadium announcement between games reminded spectators to drink water and take regular breaks from the heat.\n\nGauff collapse\n\nGauff, the world No. 2 and a strong pre-tournament contender to medal in the women's singles event, stormed into an early first-set lead, but after seeing a set point saved by Veki\u0107, she lost her break advantage when a forehand drifted wide.\n\nAs the set wore on, Veki\u0107 played the shot of the match at that point, pushing a smash back past her opponent. But Gauff responded in similar fashion the following game, returning a Veki\u0107 smash with a well-timed backhand while her opponent was stranded at the net.\n\nBoth players had set points in the tie-break, but it was Veki\u0107 who capitalized on the opportunity, raising her level when it mattered to take a one-set lead in more than an hour.\n\nVeki\u0107, a semifinalist at Wimbledon earlier this month, lost an early break with a double fault at the start of the second set, but she managed to take the next five games in a row and wrap up the victory in brutal conditions.\n\n\"It was very, very tough out there, the conditions, when we warmed up this morning and the roof was closed,\" Veki\u0107 told reporters. \"It took me a couple of games to adjust; it was very hot. The ball was flying a little bit, but after that, I got in rhythm and it was pretty good.\"\n\nThe dispute with the umpire in the second set, Gauff later explained, didn't alter the result of the match.\n\n\"I'm not going to sit here and say one point affected the result today because I was already on the losing side of things before that point happened,\" she said.\n\nThe 20-year-old, a flag bearer for Team USA at the opening ceremony, still has mixed and women's doubles competitions to come in Paris having won her opening match in the latter alongside Jessica Pegula on Saturday.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Now, here's Mike Sykes.\n\nGood morning, Winners! Welcome back to the Morning Win. Thanks for reading today. Here's your morning medal count as of 9:00 a.m. ET.\n\n-- United States: 20 (3 gold, 8 silver, 9 bronze)\n\n-- France: 16 (5 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze)\n\n-- Japan: 12 (6 gold, 2 silver, 4 bronze)\n\n-- China: 12 (5 gold, 5 silver, 2 bronze)\n\n-- Korea: 10 (5 gold, 3 silver, 2 bronze)\n\nLet's talk about Katie Ledecky!\n\nCoco Gauff deserves better\n\nThe story of Coco Gauff's loss in straight sets (7-6, 6-2) to Donna Veki\u0107 won't be about the loss.\n\nInstead, it'll be about the argument between Gauff and yet another chair umpire after an erroneous call completely derailed what felt like might be a classic.\n\nREAD MORE: Fans rallied behind a teary-eyed Coco Gauff after a bad call ruined her match\n\nWith the second set at 2-3 and Veki\u0107 playing for a breakpoint, Gauff served the ball into Veki\u0107's forehand. Gauff prepared to hit a return but the line judge called the ball out as she swung. She seemed to pull up after the call and sent the ball into the net.\n\nThe umpire correctly overruled the line judge and ruled the ball in. But the judge also ruled that Gauff lost the point, which gave Veki\u0107 the break she needed to push the match to 4-2.\n\nThat's what caused Gauff's teary-eyed reaction. She felt cheated and it's hard to blame her.\n\nA call was made and Gauff reacted to it. The call was wrong, yes, but it disrupted play. The obvious solution was to replay the point, but instead, we got a heated argument between Gauff and the chair umpire that looked completely embarrassing for the sport.\n\nThis isn't the first time this has happened to Gauff. Just over a month ago at the French Open essentially the same thing happened in Gauff's match against Iga Swiatek. Back then, Gauff argued that tennis needs a replay system to prevent things like this from happening. She's arguing it again here and, honestly, she may be right. For these errors to continue to mar the sport repeatedly isn't the greatest look.\n\nYou know what also isn't the greatest look? Gauff's reaction here. Don't get me wrong. Understandably, she's upset about what keeps happening to her. Anyone would be.\n\nThere's nothing wrong with being an emotional player. We've seen plenty come through the sport and thrive. John McEnroe is the obvious one that comes to mind. Serena Williams got fiery at times on the court, too. But they were able to use that emotion and that fire to thrive.\n\nToday, it seemed, Gauff's emotions were a bit of a hindrance. That's Ok. Gauff is young. She'll learn and get better from this.\n\nLet's hope Roland Garros learns, too, and doesn't continuously allow things to go this far.\n\nKatie Ledecky is still better than everyone else\n\nHere's our daily word from Michelle Martinelli, who has boots on the ground in Paris for the Games. Today's subject is the unmatched brilliance of Katie Ledecky. The longer she goes, the better she is.\n\nNANTERRE, France -- Bonjour, les gagnants! On Day 4 of swimming at the Paris Olympics, Katie Ledecky is doing Katie Ledecky things, like crushing her 1,500-meter freestyle competition in her typically dominant fashion.\n\nThe longer the race, the better Ledecky is, and the 1,500 is her best event -- and one that was FINALLY added to the Olympic lineup at the 2021 Tokyo Games. (It took decades, but organizers finally corrected the absurdly antiquated and sexist thinking that limited the longest Olympic women's event to the 800 when men could swim the 1,500.)\n\nThe world record holder, Ledecky was the first women's 1,500 Olympic champion in Tokyo, setting the Olympic record by default. And after her prelims swim Tuesday, she certainly looks like she'll have no trouble defending her Olympic gold.\n\nLedecky qualified first while fellow American Katie Grimes didn't make the top-8 final, set for Wednesday afternoon Eastern time.\n\nOn a personal note, as a kid watching Olympic swimming, I remember being confused about why women couldn't swim the 1,500 when 10-year-old me could. So to finally see the event in Tokyo on TV and then in person Tuesday in Paris was really something special\n\n.This was my view of Ledecky cruising to the finish in prelims:\n\nThe 10-year-old inside me is crying.\n\n-- Michelle Martinelli \ud83c\uddeb\ud83c\uddf7\n\nDon't forget: The MLB trade deadline is today\n\nOlympic buzz has overtaken just about everything. {"uri": "2024-07-437672122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:43:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:43:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T00:22:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/coco-gauff-taylor-fritz-vs-nadia-podoroska-maximo-gonzalez-2024-olympics-tennis-prediction-odds-pick", "title": "Coco Gauff/Taylor Fritz vs Nadia Podoroska/Maximo Gonzalez 2024 Olympics Tennis Prediction, Odds, Pick", "body": "Coco Gauff and Taylor Fritz take on Nadia Podoroska and Maximo Gonzalez in the 2024 Olympics tennis mixed doubles tournament. Our 2024 Olympics tennis odds series has our Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez prediction and pick. Find out how to watch Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez.\n\nThe Olympic mixed doubles tournament begins for Coco Gauff, as she pursues Olympic gold in three different tennis disciplines. She's still alive in singles. She has also advanced in the women's doubles bracket with Jessica Pegula. Now she starts her mixed doubles path to what she hopes will be the medal podium. She plays mixed doubles with Taylor Fritz. This will be the first time Gauff and Fritz have played together. It will be fascinating to watch for tennis fans who have seen these players go about their business in singles on the pro tour. Gauff does not have an elite forehand, while Fritz is a relatively conventional American male player who relies on a serve and forehand to win points. American male tennis players over the past 15 years have been serve and forehand and very little else. It's why American tennis players haven't won a major championship since Andy Roddick at the 2003 U.S. Open. However, while Fritz hasn't reached a major semifinal (he came close at Wimbledon but lost to Lorenzo Musetti in the quarterfinals), he has become a solid top-20 player, which is certainly not bad. His serve and his forehand will balance out Gauff's lack of a crushing forehand in this match.\n\nNadia Podoroska is a name diehard tennis fans are aware of. Casual fans won't recall this, but tennis junkies will remember that she reached the 2020 French Open semifinals (during the pandemic, when the tournament was played in early October). She can play ball, especially on red clay. However, she hasn't done a whole lot on tour in the four years since that achievement. Can she summon up some magic alongside veteran doubles player Maximo Gonzalez? This is an intriguing contest on many levels.\n\nHere are the Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez 2024 Olympics tennis odds, courtesy of FanDuel.\n\nOlympics Tennis Odds: Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez Odds\n\nTime: Approx. 1 p.m. ET / 10 a.m. PT -- match could start 60 minutes earlier or later depending on previous matches\n\n*Watch Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez LIVE on fuboTV (click for a free trial)*\n\nWhy Gauff / Fritz Could Cover The Spread\n\nThough Gauff and Fritz are not an experienced doubles team, they are both very talented, and as noted above, they complement each other. Gauff is better at court coverage, Fritz better as a server. Gauff is better on her backhand wing, Fritz better on the forehand side. Podoroska and Gonzalez are smart tennis players, but they aren't the better athletes. Talent wins out here.\n\nWhy Podoroska / Gonzalez Could Cover The Spread\n\nGauff and Fritz, having never played together, might lack polished communication at net when trying to change spots on court and make quick-reaction plays. Podoroska and Gonzalez should be able to make those quick decisions and handle the more complicated points in the match. That could swing the outcome in their favor.\n\nFinal Gauff Fritz vs Podoroska Gonzalez Prediction & Pick\n\nDon't overthink this one. Gauff and Fritz should win in straights. {"uri": "8251410883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:13:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:13:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:12:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/all-the-highs-and-lows-from-the-2024-summer-olympics-in-paris/", "title": "All the Highs and Lows from the Wild 2024 Summer Olympic Games in Paris", "body": "The 2024 Summer Olympics might be taking place in the City of Light, but that doesn't mean they haven't come with their fair share of darkness.\n\nFollowing a flashy opening ceremony on Friday, July 26 that continues to draw outrage from some celebrities and religious figures, the Games have been plagued by allegations of sexism and racism, controversial calls on the tennis court and even tragedy inside the Olympic Village.\n\nThe Olympics have also seen the triumphant return of Celine Dion, the emergence of a new gymnastics folk hero and, in perhaps the most heroic moment of the Games, the introduction of Bob the Cap Catcher.\n\nFor all of the highs and lows from the 2024 Summer Olympics thus far, keep scrolling.\n\nA year-and-a-half after announcing she had been diagnosed with a rare condition called stiff-person syndrome -- putting her future singing career severely at risk -- Celine Dion rose to the top of the Eiffel Tower like a phoenix.\n\nDressed in a sliver, glittery gown that took 1,000 hours to make, Dion, 56, performed a triumphant version of \u00c9dith Piaf's \"Hymne \u00e0 l'amour\" to close out the opening ceremony.\n\nThe rendition left nary a dry eye amongst the millions of viewers watching back at home and kicked the Games off on an emotional high.\n\n\"I'm honored to have performed tonight for the Paris 2024 Opening Ceremony,\" Dion shared on social media, \"and so full of joy to be back in one of my very favorite cities.\"\n\nThe opening ceremony was nothing if not audacious and dramatic, but there was one particular moment that set off a certain sector of the celebrity universe.\n\nDuring the show, a tableau featuring drag performers and other artists bared an alleged resemblance to \"The Last Supper,\" which some critics called a rebuke of religion. The French Catholic Church even said the festivities \"included scenes of derision and mockery of Christianity.\"\n\nDespite opening ceremony artistic director Thomas Jolly saying the imagery was meant to honor Dionysus, the Greek god of wine, the damage had already been done.\n\n\"To watch such an incredible event that's going to take place over the next two weeks and see the opening ceremonies complexly blasphemed and mock the Christian faith with their interpretation of the Last Supper was disgusting,\" actress Candace Cameron Bure said in a video posted via Instagram.\n\nKansas City Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker also chimed in, quoting a Bible verse that said \"God is not mocked.\"\n\nFrench DJ Barbara Butch, who was at the center of the tableau in a gold headpiece, has been \"the target of an extremely violent campaign of cyber-harassment and defamation,\" Butch's lawyer Audrey Msellati claimed in a statement via Instagram on Monday, July 29.\n\nThe statement continued, \"She has been threatened with death, torture and rape and has also been the target of numerous anti-Semitic, homophobic, sexist and anti-grossophobic insults.\"\n\nAccording to Msellati, Butch, 43, is planning to file several complaints and \"intends to prosecute anyone who tries to intimidate her in the future.\"\n\nIt only took Stephen Nedoroscik 45 seconds to become a legend.\n\nThe 25-year-old Team USA gymnast, who excels at pommel horse, needed to execute his routine perfectly on Monday, July 29, to earn the American men their first team medal since 2008.\n\nNedoroscik did not let his team down. The Worcester, Massachusetts native was brilliant on the pommel horse, embraced by his coaches and teammates after leaving the mat. The squad took home bronze.\n\nBut it wasn't just the athletic achievement that made Stephen Nedoroscik into a national icon -- it was also the memes.\n\nNedoroscik, who his coach Syque Caesar calls \"quirky, funny, goofy\" and someone who \"dances to his own tune,\" was seen on camera before his routine wearing glasses, often with his eyes shut getting into the zone.\n\n\"Obsessed with this one guy on the US men's gymnastics team who looks like he's getting his phd in anthropology and his only job is pommel horse,\" one viewer wrote via X.\n\nNedoroscik was noticeably spectacle-less when he took the floor for his now-iconic routine. There's a simple reason for that.\n\n\"I don't need to see when I do pommel horse,\" he explained. \"It's all by feel.\"\n\nDuring her match against Donna Vekic on Tuesday, July 30, American tennis star Coco Gauff was overcome with emotion when a controversial call went against her.\n\nAfter a deep serve return from Vekic, 28, was initially called out by a line judge, chair umpire Jaume Campistol ruled the ball was in, rewarding the point and a crucial service break to Vekic. Gauff argued the point should have been replayed.\n\n\"I never argue these calls. But [the line judge] called it out before I hit the ball,\" Gauff said to Campistol. \"It's not even a perception; it's the rules.\"\n\nAfter wiping tears from her face, Gauff was not able to recover and lost the match in straight sets 7-6, 6-2.\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that happened to me, where I feel like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff told reporters.\n\nThe incident happened on the exact same court where Gauff ran into a similar issue during her semifinal match against Iga Swiatek at the French Open in June.\n\nAfter a disputed call on one of Swiatek's serves led to Gauff losing a point, Gauff called for a universal video review system.\n\n\"Tennis is the only sport where not only we don't have the VR system, but a lot of times the decisions are made by one person. In other sports there are usually multiple refs making a decision,\" Gauff said post-match.\n\nNot all heroes wear capes, and sometimes they're not wearing much of anything at all.\n\nBefore a women's 100m breaststroke heat on Sunday, July 28, American swimmer Emma Weber dropped her swim cap in the pool, which floated all the way down to the bottom.\n\nIn a moment's notice, a Speedo-clad man leapt into action to retrieve the cap from the depths of the water at Paris La Defense Arena, who the NBC Sports broadcast affectionately named \"Bob the Cap Catcher.\"\n\nAccording to an Olympics spokesperson, Bob was a lifeguard on duty who was dutifully called into action.\n\n\"As the lifeguards are the only people wearing swimwear, apart from the athletes, a request may be made to fetch an item at the bottom of the pool prior to the next race,\" the statement explained. \"In this case, the request was made to the lifeguard closest to the item.\"\n\nThe spokesperson also said Bob -- whose real name remains a mystery -- was refusing all media requests, hoping to keep the focus on the swimmers themselves.\n\nA true Olympic hero.\n\nVeteran TV broadcaster Bob Ballard was dropped by Eurosport after controversial comments he made Saturday, July 27, during the conclusion of the women's 4\u00d7100 meter freestyle relay.\n\nAfter the Australian team won gold, Ballard, 82, made a remark about their delay in exiting the pool deck at the Paris Aquatic Center.\n\n\"Well, the women just finishing off,\" Ballard said. You know what women are like, hanging around, doing their makeup.\"\n\nBallard's Eurosport cohost and former Olympian Lizzie Simmonds immediately criticized his comment on air.\n\n\"Outrageous, Bob,\" Simmons said. \"Some of the men are doing that as well.\"\n\nIn a statement posted via social media on Monday, July 29, Ballard said, \"The comments I made during the Australian freestyle relay victory ceremony on Saturday have caused some offense. It was never my intention to upset or belittle anyone and, if I did, I apologize. I am a massive advocate of women's sport.\"\n\nThe Kelces attended USA's field hockey game against Argentina on Saturday, July 27, where Jason donned a beret that he found at \"a souvenir shop.\"\n\nThe next day, Jason said he was \"officially a fan\" of women's rugby after meeting the American team and even competed against breakout star Ilona Maher in an arm wrestling contest.\n\nJason's presence rubbed off on the Team USA squad, who took home the bronze medal in dramatic fashion on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nWhile that was happening, though, Jason and Kylie were seen taking in Simone Biles and Team USA earning gold in the women's gymnastics team event.\n\nNot a bad Parisian getaway.\n\nBefore the official start of the Games on Tuesday, July 23, the sister-in-law of U.S. women's water polo player Maggie Steffens died in the Olympic Village.\n\nLulu Conner had traveled to Paris to see her husband's sister compete, but died after \"a medical emergency,\" according to the Associated Press. She was 26.\n\nIn an interview published by People on Monday, July 29, Steffens, 31, called Conner \"a light.\" Steffens added, \"She was somebody that brought joy to everybody she was with and to everything she did.\"\n\nOn Friday, July 26, Samoan boxing coach Lionel Elika Fatupaito died inside the Olympic Village. He was 60.\n\nThe Samoa Association of Sport and National Olympic Committee confirmed the tragedy, saying he died due to \"natural causes.\"\n\n\"Lionel was one of Samoa's top boxing coaches and a great believer in the Olympic ideal,\" SASNOC President Pauga Talalelei Pauga shared in the statement. \"Our thoughts and those of the entire Samoan sporting community are with Lionel's family, his boxers, and friends. He will be greatly missed.\"\n\nElika Fatupaito was at the game supporting Ato Plodzicki-Faoagali, who fought in his coach's absence on Sunday, July 28, ultimately falling to Belgian Victor Schelstraete in the round of 16.\n\nRyan Murphy -- the Team USA Olympic swimmer, not the TV producer -- was surprised with a celebratory sex reveal by his wife after taking home his seventh medal all-time.\n\nAfter Murphy, 29, earned bronze in the men's 100m backstroke on Monday, July 29, his wife, Bridget Konttinin, held up a sign that read, \"Ryan, it's a girl!\"\n\nMurphy eventually made his way over to Konttinin and gave her a kiss in front of his crowd of supporters.\n\n\"A night we'll never forget,\" Konttinin wrote via her Instagram Stories. \"I love you so much.\"\n\nBritish rugby player Amy Wilson-Hardy was pulled from competing in the Olympics after an investigation was launched into alleged racist behavior.\n\nAccording to The Independent, Wilson-Hardy, 32, was the subject of the investigation after a WhatsApp message was discovered of the athlete in blackface.\n\nIn a statement, Team Great Britain announced Wilson-Hardy left the team \"on medical grounds.\" She was replaced on the team by Abi Burton.\n\n\"We heard about [it] this morning, but for us, [it's about] focusing on the games, focusing on getting ourselves in the right place to be able to perform,\" team captain Emma Uren told reporters on Tuesday, July 30. \"Because we're off our phones, we don't know much about it. And we didn't get told much about it because we know that we need to focus on the tournament. So our heads are 100 percent there.\"\n\nWilson-Hardy has yet to comment on the investigation.\n\nIn the thick of qualifying on Sunday, July 28, the Team USA women's gymnastics team still found time to drop it like it was hot.\n\nThankfully, the moment was all caught on camera by NBC Sports. \"Anybody have more fun than Snoop? I don't think so,\" commentator Terry Gannon said.\n\nSnoop has been a mainstay in Paris throughout the Games, showing his love for Team USA at every turn. He's hit the pool with Michael Phelps, practiced with the American fencing team and even hopped on NBC to offer his own commentary.", "source": {"uri": "usmagazine.com", "dataType": "news", "title": A line judge initially called the shot out of bounds, but it was actually in. However, because of the \u00e2\u20ac\u0153out\u00e2\u20ac call, Gauff did not keep the ball in play and hit it into the net afterward. The chair umpire, Jaume Campistol, awarded Vekic the point because he believed the \u00e2\u20ac\u0153out\u00e2\u20ac call shouldn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t have affected Gauff\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s swing.\n\nGauff was visibly upset and could be seen pleading her case to the umpire to the extent that the reigning U.S. Open champion was ultimately brought to tears over the unfair ruling.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153He called it out before I hit it so I went up on the ball,\u00e2\u20ac Gauff could be heard telling the ump on the broadcast. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153This isn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t fair, he called it out before I hit the ball\u00e2\u20ac| If he called it out before I hit it, it affects the swing.\u00e2\u20ac\u00c2\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153I know I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122m wrong, but I cannot change my decision after your appeal,\u00e2\u20ac the ump told Gauff at one point.\u00c2\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153I never argue these calls,\u00e2\u20ac Gauff said through tears. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153You don\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t understand, I have to always advocate for myself on this court all the time.\u00e2\u20ac\u00c2\n\nA referee was then brought onto the court to mediate the dispute.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153This isn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t fair,\u00e2\u20ac Gauff continued. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153I feel like I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122m getting cheated on constantly in this game. {"uri": "8251452162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:02:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:02:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:01:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/photos-and-takeaways-from-paris-olympics-day-4", "title": "Photos and takeaways from Paris Olympics Day 4", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Simone Biles reached the top of the podium yet again, cementing her legacy as the greatest American gymnast and one of the best athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nBiles helped the United States win the women's team event Tuesday to secure her fifth Olympic gold medal and put the U.S. back on top of the sport after a second-place finish three years ago in Tokyo.\n\nGold medallist Simone Biles of United States stands on the podium at the Paris 2024 Olympics on July 30, 2024. Photo by Dylan Martinez/ Reuters\n\nBiles became the most decorated American gymnast in front of a crowd that included Nicole Kidman, Natalie Portman, Serena Williams, Spike Lee, Michael Phelps and Nadia Comaneci at a raucous Bercy Arena.\n\nSimone Biles of United States in action on the Floor Exercise. Photo by Athit Perawongmetha/ REUTERS\n\nIt was the eighth Olympic medal for the 27-year-old Biles, who was previously tied with Shannon Miller at seven.\n\nItaly won the silver medal, and Brazil got the bronze.\n\nSunisa Lee competes in the floor exercise event of the artistic gymnastics women's team final during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Bercy Arena in Paris, on July 30, 2024. Photo by LOIC VENANCE/ AFP via Getty Images\n\nThere were no such triumphs in swimming for the Americans, who couldn't manage more than silver and bronze medals. In tennis, it was Coco Gauff left fuming over an officiating decision in a loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia.\n\nThere were no winners or losers in men's triathlon, which was as postponed because of concerns about the water quality in the Seine River amid a heat wave that made life difficult on some athletes and fans in Paris.\n\nSunisa Lee of United States in action on the balance beam. Photo by Dylan Martinez/ Reuters\n\nU.S. swimming woes\n\nAustralian Kaylee McKeown knocked off world record holder Regan Smith of the United States in the 100 backstroke to defend her the title from the Tokyo Games.\n\nSmith couldn't hold off the hard-charging Aussie, who touched the wall in 57.33 seconds to win by a relatively comfortable margin over Smith's 57.66. The U.S. also grabbed the bronze with Katharine Berkoff.\n\nMen's 100m Freestyle at Paris La Defense Arena, Nanterre, France on July 30, 2024. Photo by Agustin Marcarian/ Reuters\n\nIn the men's 800 freestyle, Daniel Wiffen won Ireland's first gold medal in swimming since scandal-plagued Michelle Smith won three events in 1996. Defending champion Bobby Finke of the U.S. got the silver.\n\nThe night's other gold medal went to Britain, which defended its title in the men's 4\u00d7200 freestyle relay, with the U.S. earning yet another silver.\n\nJames Guy of Britain, Tom Dean of Britain and Matthew Richards of Britain all react to the Men's 4 x 200m freestyle relay final. Photo by Clodagh Kilcoyne/ Reuters\n\nGauff upset\n\nThe scene felt all too familiar to Gauff. An officiating decision she was sure was wrong. A chair umpire who wouldn't listen. Tears streaming down her cheeks. And, most disappointing of all, a loss, this time at the Paris Games.\n\nCoco Gauff of the United States talks with an official during her match against Donna Vekic of Croatia. Photo by Edgar Su/ Reuters\n\nEven the site was the same: Court Philippe Chatrier was where the reigning U.S. Open champion was eliminated in the third round at the Summer Games by Donna Vekic of Croatia 7-6 (7), 6-2.\n\nThat's also the main stadium used annually for the French Open, where Gauff found herself in a nearly identical dispute over a call while being defeated by eventual champion Iga Swiatek in the semifinals last month.\n\nThe hand of Coco Gauff is seen during her match against Donna Vekic of Croatia. Photo by Edgar Su/ Reuters\n\n\"There's been multiple times this year where that's happened to me -- where I felt like I always have to be an advocate for myself on the court,\" Gauff said afterward, renewing a call for video review to be used in tennis, as it is in many other professional sports.\n\nGauff was the female flag bearer for the United States during the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nCarlos Alcaraz of Spain and Rafael Nadal of Spain react during their match against Tallon Griekspoor of Netherlands and Wesley Koolhof of Netherlands. Photo by Claudia Greco/ Reuters\n\nAlso in tennis, Rafael Nadal and Carlos Alcaraz advanced into the doubles quarterfinals with a 6-4, 6-7 (2), 10-2 match tiebreaker victory over Tallon Griekspoor and Wesley Koolhof of the Netherlands.\n\nNo. 1-ranked Iga Swiatek defeated No. 52 Wang Xiyu of China 6-2, 6-4.\n\nTriathlon postponed\n\nThe men's triathlon scheduled for Tuesday was postponed because of concerns about the water quality in the Seine River.\n\nIt was rescheduled for Wednesday, when the women's competition is also slated to be held. But both will happen only if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is also planned as a backup date.\n\nThere is rain forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate rescheduling because rain generally causes an increase in bacteria levels in the Seine, the long-polluted waterway that has gone through an expensive cleanup effort.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider said. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nHeat wave\n\nAfter enduring the rain in the opening ceremony, athletes now are having to deal with the heat.\n\nMost of France is under heat warnings, with temperatures in Paris hitting 36 degrees Celsius (97 Fahrenheit), the national weather agency said. Air conditioning is far less common in French homes, shops and restaurants than in places like the United States.\n\nThe heat was even worse in the south, including the region around the Mediterranean cities of Marseille and Nice that are hosting Olympic competitions like soccer and sailing. It was as hot as 41 C (105 F) in parts of southern France.\n\nBefore winning the gold Tuesday, Biles posted a video on Instagram while struggling with the lack of air conditioning.\n\n\"Don't come for me about my hair,\" Biles wrote on Instagram before the gymnastics team final. \"IT WAS DONE but bus has NO AC and it's like 9,000 degrees. {"uri": "8247942252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-28", "time": "22:05:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-28T22:05:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-28T22:04:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://brobible.com/sports/article/coco-gauff-olympic-village-paris-stranded/", "title": "US Tennis Team Strands Coco Gauff In Olympic Village Due To Crowded Conditions", "body": "Many have a romanticized view of the Olympic Village at a Summer Olympics, as getting to spend nearly three weeks with the world's greatest athletes in an iconic city with great weather seems awesome. But, life in the village isn't always as glamorous as you'd like to think, and Coco Gauff and her tennis teammates have proved just that.\n\nAfter starting out sleeping on the cardboard beds in the Olympic Village in Paris, France, Coco revealed that all of her Team USA Women's Tennis teammates had left the Olympic Village for the greener pastures of a local hotel.\n\nThings are tight in the Olympic Village, with small living quarters and as many as five people sharing one bathroom. While that may be fine for college students, WTA tennis players are used to great accommodations as they travel around the world trying to earn a living playing tennis.\n\nIn the comments of that TikTok, a commenter said that they would move to a hotel. Coco Gauff responded by saying, \"all the tennis girls moved to a hotel except me. so now just 5 girls two bathrooms.\"\n\nCoco Gauff has been very busy in Paris. She was named the flag-bearer by a vote of all of Team USA's 600+ members, quite the honor at just 20 years of age.\n\nShe's busy on the court, too. The world-number-two is playing in all three disciplines, as she's also playing in the Women's Doubles with usual teammate Jessica Pegula and is teaming up with Taylor Fritz in Mixed Doubles. While the Mixed Doubles tournament has not started yet, she's won her first round matches in both singles and doubles.\n\nThis year's Olympic Tennis Tournament is taking place at Roland Garros in Paris, home of the French Open.", "source": {"uri": "brobible.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BroBible"}, "authors": [{"uri": "garrett_carr@brobible.com", "name": "Garrett Carr", "type": "author",
