Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nUS women win a first Olympic medal in rugby sevens with comeback victory over Australia\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Alex Sedrick ran most of the length of the field to give the U.S. women a first Olympic rugby sevens medal with a stunning stoppage-time comeback win over Australia in the bronze-medal match. The 2016 champion Australians were leading 12-7 with seconds remaining and deep in U.S. territory. The ball went to Sedrick and she bumped off two tacklers before racing all the way to the other end to spark jubilation for the Americans. The Americans rushed onto the field to celebrate the 14-12 victory. The U.S. women reached the Olympic semifinals for the first time and lost to defending champion New Zealand.\n\nFrench police investigating abuse targeting Olympic opening ceremony DJ over 'Last Supper' scene\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. French prosecutors on Tuesday ordered police to investigate complaints from a DJ and LGBTQ+ icon that she suffered a torrent of online threats and abuse after performing in contentious scenes at the Games' opening ceremony. A lawyer for DJ Barbara Butch told The Associated Press that she filed a formal legal complaint alleging online harassment, death threats, and insults. The lawyer said the complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator or perpetrators of the alleged crimes. The Paris prosecutor's office confirmed that it received Butch's complaint and tasked a police unit that specializes in fighting hate crimes to investigate.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nPatrick Willis' short but impactful career leads him to Hall of Fame\n\nSANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- From the day he stepped into the NFL until a foot injury forced him into retirement after eight brilliant seasons as a do-everything linebacker, Patrick Willis succeeded at the highest level. He won the AP Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2007, was a five first-team All-Pro, a seven-time Pro Bowler and a member of the All-Decade team for the 2010s. None of those lofty honors will match the one coming to Willis on Saturday night when he will be enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Only he wasn't at Le Golf National. He was spotted playing the Old Course at St. Andrews on Monday with a thousand or so spectators gathered around the 18th hole. McIlroy sees the Olympics as a chance to redeem himself from his last performance. That was a missed cut at the British Open, ending another year without a major. Biles is competing after tweaking her left calf during qualifying. The five-woman US squad of Biles, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey and Hezly Rivera are heavily favored to return to the top of the medal stand after finishing second to Russia at the Tokyo Games three years ago. The Americans will be paired with Italy the runner-up to Biles during all-around qualifying.\n\nThe Latest: Simone Biles and Team USA are rolling toward gold in Olympics gymnastics finals\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Simone Biles and the U.S. women are leading the gymnastics team final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, building on a sizeable 3-point margin over Italy after two rotations.\n\nCoco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff got into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match. Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nFrench police investigating abuse targeting Olympic opening ceremony DJ over 'Last Supper' scene\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. French prosecutors on Tuesday ordered police to investigate complaints from a DJ and LGBTQ+ icon that she suffered a torrent of online threats and abuse after performing in contentious scenes at the Games' opening ceremony. A lawyer for DJ Barbara Butch told The Associated Press that she filed a formal legal complaint alleging online harassment, death threats, and insults. The lawyer said the complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator or perpetrators of the alleged crimes. The Paris prosecutor's office confirmed that it received Butch's complaint and tasked a police unit that specializes in fighting hate crimes to investigate.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nPatrick Willis' short but impactful career leads him to Hall of Fame\n\nSANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- From the day he stepped into the NFL until a foot injury forced him into retirement after eight brilliant seasons as a do-everything linebacker, Patrick Willis succeeded at the highest level. He won the AP Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2007, was a five first-team All-Pro, a seven-time Pro Bowler and a member of the All-Decade team for the 2010s. None of those lofty honors will match the one coming to Willis on Saturday night when he will be enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Only he wasn't at Le Golf National. He was spotted playing the Old Course at St. Andrews on Monday with a thousand or so spectators gathered around the 18th hole. McIlroy sees the Olympics as a chance to redeem himself from his last performance. That was a missed cut at the British Open, ending another year without a major. Can a gold fill the void of 10 years without a major? For now, he says it would be his biggest feat in 10 years.\n\nOlympic swimming: Ledecky is fastest in heats of 1500; Marchand advances in 2 more races\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Katie Ledecky got started on what she hopes will be her first gold medal of the Paris Olympics, fastest in the heats of the 1,500-meter freestyle. Finishing more than a half-lap ahead of the closest swimmer in her heat, Ledecky posted a time of 15 minutes, 47.43 seconds. She'll have the prime lane for the final Wednesday. Ledecky is looking to earn her 12th Olympic medal. Coming off his dominating victory in the men's 400 individual medley, L\u00e9on Marchand of France is attempting a double in the 200 butterfly and 200 breaststroke, advancing to the semifinals in both Biles is competing after tweaking her left calf during qualifying. The five-woman US squad of Biles, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey and Hezly Rivera are heavily favored to return to the top of the medal stand after finishing second to Russia at the Tokyo Games three years ago. The Americans will be paired with Italy the runner-up to Biles during all-around qualifying.\n\nThe Latest: Simone Biles and US women compete in Olympic gymnastics team final\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Simone Biles leads the U.S. women into the gymnastics team final today at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The Americans are heavily favored to win gold after finishing runner-up to Russia in 2021.\n\nCoco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff got into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match. Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nFrench police investigating abuse targeting Olympic opening ceremony DJ over 'Last Supper' scene\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. French prosecutors on Tuesday ordered police to investigate complaints from a DJ and LGBTQ+ icon that she suffered a torrent of online threats and abuse after performing in contentious scenes at the Games' opening ceremony. A lawyer for DJ Barbara Butch told The Associated Press that she filed a formal legal complaint alleging online harassment, death threats, and insults. The lawyer said the complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator or perpetrators of the alleged crimes. The Paris prosecutor's office confirmed that it received Butch's complaint and tasked a police unit that specializes in fighting hate crimes to investigate.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nPatrick Willis' short but impactful career leads him to Hall of Fame\n\nSANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- From the day he stepped into the NFL until a foot injury forced him into retirement after eight brilliant seasons as a do-everything linebacker, Patrick Willis succeeded at the highest level. He won the AP Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2007, was a five first-team All-Pro, a seven-time Pro Bowler and a member of the All-Decade team for the 2010s. None of those lofty honors will match the one coming to Willis on Saturday night when he will be enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Only he wasn't at Le Golf National. He was spotted playing the Old Course at St. Andrews on Monday with a thousand or so spectators gathered around the 18th hole. McIlroy sees the Olympics as a chance to redeem himself from his last performance. That was a missed cut at the British Open, ending another year without a major. Can a gold fill the void of 10 years without a major? For now, he says it would be his biggest feat in 10 years.\n\nOlympic swimming: Ledecky is fastest in heats of 1500; Marchand advances in 2 more races\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Katie Ledecky got started on what she hopes will be her first gold medal of the Paris Olympics, fastest in the heats of the 1,500-meter freestyle. Finishing more than a half-lap ahead of the closest swimmer in her heat, Ledecky posted a time of 15 minutes, 47.43 seconds. She'll have the prime lane for the final Wednesday. Ledecky is looking to earn her 12th Olympic medal. The 30-year-old Sims has a 3.57 ERA with 40 strikeouts in 35 1/3 innings over 43 appearances. The veteran made 210 appearances for the Reds, posting a 3.94 ERA since 2018. The Reds received a 19-year-old prospect, right-handed pitcher Ovis Portes. The 2016 champion Australians were leading 12-7 with seconds remaining and deep in U.S. territory. The ball went to Sedrick and she bumped off two tacklers before racing all the way to the other end to spark jubilation for the Americans. {"uri": "8251095873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:37:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:37:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:35:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/ap/sports/ap-sports-summarybrief-at-1-20-p-m-edt/article_37654585-aa47-50f9-823b-f6021f7936be.html", "title": "AP Sports SummaryBrief at 1:20 p.m. EDT", "body": "Simone Biles and Team USA take aim at gold in the women's gymnastics team final\n\nPARIS (AP) -- American gymnastics star Simone Biles is inside Bercy Arena for the women's team final. Biles is competing after tweaking her left calf during qualifying. The five-woman US squad of Biles, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey and Hezly Rivera are heavily favored to return to the top of the medal stand after finishing second to Russia at the Tokyo Games three years ago. The Americans will be paired with Italy the runner-up to Biles during all-around qualifying.\n\nThe Latest: Simone Biles and US women are crusing at the Olympics gymnastics team finals\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Simone Biles and the U.S. women are leading the gymnastics team final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, building on a sizeable 3-point margin over Italy after two rotations.\n\nCoco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff got into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match. Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nFrench police investigating abuse targeting Olympic opening ceremony DJ over 'Last Supper' scene\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. French prosecutors on Tuesday ordered police to investigate complaints from a DJ and LGBTQ+ icon that she suffered a torrent of online threats and abuse after performing in contentious scenes at the Games' opening ceremony. A lawyer for DJ Barbara Butch told The Associated Press that she filed a formal legal complaint alleging online harassment, death threats, and insults. The lawyer said the complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator or perpetrators of the alleged crimes. The Paris prosecutor's office confirmed that it received Butch's complaint and tasked a police unit that specializes in fighting hate crimes to investigate.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nPatrick Willis' short but impactful career leads him to Hall of Fame\n\nSANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- From the day he stepped into the NFL until a foot injury forced him into retirement after eight brilliant seasons as a do-everything linebacker, Patrick Willis succeeded at the highest level. He won the AP Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2007, was a five first-team All-Pro, a seven-time Pro Bowler and a member of the All-Decade team for the 2010s. None of those lofty honors will match the one coming to Willis on Saturday night when he will be enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Only he wasn't at Le Golf National. He was spotted playing the Old Course at St. Andrews on Monday with a thousand or so spectators gathered around the 18th hole. McIlroy sees the Olympics as a chance to redeem himself from his last performance. That was a missed cut at the British Open, ending another year without a major. Can a gold fill the void of 10 years without a major? For now, he says it would be his biggest feat in 10 years.\n\nOlympic swimming: Ledecky is fastest in heats of 1500; Marchand advances in 2 more races\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Katie Ledecky got started on what she hopes will be her first gold medal of the Paris Olympics, fastest in the heats of the 1,500-meter freestyle. Finishing more than a half-lap ahead of the closest swimmer in her heat, Ledecky posted a time of 15 minutes, 47.43 seconds. She'll have the prime lane for the final Wednesday. Ledecky is looking to earn her 12th Olympic medal. Coming off his dominating victory in the men's 400 individual medley, L\u00e9on Marchand of France is attempting a double in the 200 butterfly and 200 breaststroke, advancing to the semifinals in both {"uri": "2024-07-438554839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:28:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:28:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:19:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/ap-sports-summarybrief-at-12-19-p-m-edt/article_2a2d7ae2-eb3d-57fe-b8ee-44628549a0fe.html", "title": "AP Sports SummaryBrief at 12:19 p.m. EDT", "body": "Simone Biles and Team USA take aim at gold in the women's gymnastics team final\n\nPARIS (AP) -- American gymnastics star Simone Biles is inside Bercy Arena for the women's team final. Biles is competing after tweaking her left calf during qualifying. The five-woman US squad of Biles, Sunisa Lee, Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey and Hezly Rivera are heavily favored to return to the top of the medal stand after finishing second to Russia at the Tokyo Games three years ago. The Americans will be paired with Italy the runner-up to Biles during all-around qualifying.\n\nThe Latest: Simone Biles and US women compete in Olympic gymnastics team final\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Simone Biles leads the U.S. women into the gymnastics team final today at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The Americans are heavily favored to win gold after finishing runner-up to Russia in 2021. Competition begins at 6:15 p.m. CEST (12:15 a.m. EST) at Bercy Arena.\n\nCoco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff got into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match. Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nFrench police investigating abuse targeting Olympic opening ceremony DJ over 'Last Supper' scene\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. French prosecutors on Tuesday ordered police to investigate complaints from a DJ and LGBTQ+ icon that she suffered a torrent of online threats and abuse after performing in contentious scenes at the Games' opening ceremony. A lawyer for DJ Barbara Butch told The Associated Press that she filed a formal legal complaint alleging online harassment, death threats, and insults. The lawyer said the complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator or perpetrators of the alleged crimes. The Paris prosecutor's office confirmed that it received Butch's complaint and tasked a police unit that specializes in fighting hate crimes to investigate.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Only he wasn't at Le Golf National. He was spotted playing the Old Course at St. Andrews on Monday with a thousand or so spectators gathered around the 18th hole. The Americans are heavily favored to win gold after finishing runner-up to Russia in 2021. Competition begins at 6:15 p.m. CEST (12:15 a.m. EST) at Bercy Arena.\n\nCoco Gauff loses an argument with the chair umpire and a match to Donna Vekic at the Paris Olympics\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Coco Gauff got into an extended argument with the chair umpire over a ruling during the reigning U.S. Open champion's 7-6 (7), 6-2 loss to Donna Vekic of Croatia in a Paris Olympics third-round singles match. Gauff already was trailing by a lot when the episode happened two games from the end of the match. Gauff hit a serve and Vekic's return landed near the baseline. A line judge initially called Vekic's shot out; Gauff did not keep the ball in play. Chair umpire Jaume Campistol thought Vekic's shot landed in and awarded her the point, giving her a service break and a 4-2 lead. Gauff walked over to talk to the official and play was delayed for several minutes.\n\nOlympic opening ceremony DJ filing legal complaints for online abuse over 'Last Supper' tableau\n\nPARIS (AP) -- A storm of outrage about the Paris Olympics' opening ceremony has taken a legal turn. A DJ who performed at the show posted Tuesday that her lawyer is filing complaints over abuse that the LGBTQ+ icon has suffered online. In an interview, Barbara Butch's lawyer told The Associated Press that she had filed a formal legal complaint alleging cyberharassment, death threats, and insults. The complaint doesn't name any specific perpetrator. Although the ceremony's artistic director has repeatedly said that he wasn't inspired by \"The Last Supper,\" critics including Donald Trump have criticized that part of the show as a mockery of Leonardo Da Vinci's painting showing Christ and his apostles.\n\nMen's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon. Officials on Tuesday say they hope the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway Wednesday or in the coming days following an expensive cleanup effort. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only go forward if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river. However, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nSophia Smith contributes to reborn US attack at the Olympics\n\nSophia Smith, along with Mallory Swanson and Trinity Rodman, are helping the United States reclaim its status as a team to be feared at the Olympics in France. Smith scored both of her goals in the team's 4-1 victory on Sunday over Germany that clinched the Americans a spot in the quarterfinals at their first major tournament under coach Emma Hayes. The United States' reputation has slipped a bit in recent years following the team's bronze medal in Tokyo and disappointment at the World Cup.\n\nAnother Chinese doping controversy pops up during Olympic swimming competition\n\nNANTERRE, France (AP) -- Another Chinese doping allegation has flared up at the Paris Games, angering some swimmers who say officials need to enforce drug-testing rules consistently. The New York Times reported Tuesday that two top Chinese swimmers -- one on the Olympic team -- tested positive for a banned drug in 2022 but were eventually cleared by Chinese officials. Anti-doping officials say the athletes were cleared because a Chinese investigation determined that they accidentally ate tainted beef.\n\nRory McIlroy hoping Olympic gold can help fill a void of 10 years without silver major trophies\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France (AP) -- Rory McIlroy was the center of attention as he began preparations for the Olympics. Those were among the flurry of trades Monday by playoff hopeful teams on the day before the MLB deadline. Kansas City got veteran right-hander Michael Lorenzen. The NL West-leading Los Angeles Dodgers got hard-throwing reliever Michael Kopeck in the three-team deal that sent Fedde and outfielder Tommy Pham from the lowly White Sox to the Cardinals. Houston and Seattle are in a tight race for the AL West lead, and both acquired players from Toronto. {"uri": "8248697094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "10:27:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T10:27:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T10:26:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/why-athletes-are-leaving-paris-2024-olympic-village/", "title": "The reason why athletes are moving out of Paris 2024's Olympic Village", "body": "Highlights Coco Gauff has revealed athletes are moving out of Paris 2024 Olympic Village due to the living conditions. Gauff's TikTok video exposed the cramped nature of the room she was sharing with nine other women. Some athletes have departed the Olympic Village while other stars such as LeBron James opted to stay elsewhere from the beginning of the games.\n\nUSA's Coco Gauff has revealed why some athletes have opted to move out of Paris 2024's Olympic Village. She claimed to be the last member of America's women's tennis team to still be staying there, with her teammates deciding to book a hotel instead.\n\nThe Olympic Village is designed to home the participating athletes throughout the duration of the games, but with stars moving to accommodation elsewhere, the facilities in Paris have been called into question. Gauff posted a TikTok video showing the conditions in the room she is staying in with nine other women's athletes.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: The Olympic Village at Paris 2024 is a brand new facility which reportedly cost $1.6 billion.\n\nHer video came with the caption '10 girls, two bathrooms #olympicvillage' while showing the 20-year-old moving through the room in which other athletes were getting ready. It has led to questions surrounding the suitability of the facilities in Paris. Watch the video below:\n\nRelated How Team USA is Doing in the 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nLed by LeBron James, Stephen Curry, and Kevin Durant, Team USA is expected to bag its 17th Gold Medal in Olympics Basketball.\n\nAthletes Leave Olympic Village Gauff is the last remaining USA women's tennis player\n\nShortly after uploading the initial video, Gauff confirmed her Team USA teammates had moved out of the Olympic Village, as she noted: \"Well it's only 5 girls now so I have the room alone. My roommates are very chill. I love it.\" So, despite the controversy faced by the accommodation, the tennis player is enjoying herself.\n\nThe same can't be said of all athletes, as there has been plenty of talk about the uncomfortable cardboard beds in the rooms and a lack of general space. The latter can be seen in Gauff's clip - which has been viewed over 500,000 times - as everything appears to be very cramped.\n\nRelated Olympic Village Runs Out of Food\n\nAthletes in Paris saw high-protein items such as chicken and eggs rationed...\n\nTilly Kearns, the Australian water polo player, has publicly slammed the bed situation as she posted on social media: \"Already had a massage to undo the damage. My back is about to fall off.\" This came after Team Australia told their swimmers they could only spend 48 hours in the Olympic Village after their event. After which they would need to go home or find alternative accommodation. This decision didn't go down well with those impacted.\n\nSome Athletes Didn't Stay in Olympic Village LeBron James is among those to have found other accomodation\n\nGauff was handed the honour of being a flag bearer for Team USA at the opening ceremony. She did so alongside basketball superstar LeBron James. The LA Lakers star and the rest of the American basketball team decided to avoid staying in the Olympic Village altogether.\n\nDaniel Smith - Team USA's Olympic Village Director - previously stated that athletes would need to make their own plans if they opted against staying in the village. Smith said (per People): \"If a sport decides not to stay in [the village], they have to find their own arrangements in terms of where they're going to stay, and make their own hotel contracts.\"\n\nHe continued to add: \"A challenge with that is that basically you're outside of the bubble at that point and Paris 2024 won't provide you transportation from your specific hotel. All of the meals, all of those additional pieces that come along with logistics that athletes in the Village get, you stay out and all of that is on you.\"\n\nRelated Shocking Abandoned Olympics Venues From Over the Years\n\nPlaces such as Athens, Beijing, and Rio have seen massive stadiums and arenas get abandoned and left to rot after hosting the Olympics.", "source": {"uri": frames.\n\n'Already had a massage to undo the damage,' Kearns moaned via social media, as Palm chimed in, 'My back is about to fall off.'\n\nTeam USA's Olympic Village Director Daniel Smith previously told People that athletes can choose whether or not they want to stay in the Village.\n\nMany high-profile athletes, including LeBron James and Stephen Curry on the men's basketball team, are staying off-site in luxury digs.\n\n'If a sport decides not to stay in [the village], they have to find their own arrangements in terms of where they're going to stay, and make their own hotel contracts,' added.\n\n'All of the meals, all of those additional pieces that come along with logistics that athletes in the Village get, you stay out and all of that is on you.'\n\nIt comes one day after Gauff {"uri": "8249484086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:48:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:48:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:48:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3294117748737335, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/sports/olympics/paris-olympic-village-hotels-athletes-rcna164040", "title": "Some athletes are ditching the Olympic Village for hotels", "body": "If you build it, they will come -- but they might not stay.\n\nThe cramped bedroom quarters inside the Olympic Village at the Paris Games have apparently raised eyebrows among some athletes, including a few who chose to ditch their new digs for hotel rooms.\n\nIn a video on TikTok, Team USA tennis star Coco Gauff gave her followers a seven-second tour of the tight spaces where women were trying to do their hair and makeup. \"10 girls, two bathrooms,\" Gauff wrote in a text overlay. (The video was accompanied by screaming sound effects drawn from the horror movies \"Pearl\" and \"Hereditary.\")\n\n\"I would go to a hotel,\" a TikTok user commented. Gauff's reply: \"all the tennis girls moved to a hotel except me. so now just 5 girls two bathrooms.\" She elaborated in another reply: \"well it's only 5 girls now so I have the room alone. roommates are very chill.\"\n\nIt was not clear exactly why the tennis players left the village.\n\nThe minimalist sleeping areas are a time-honored Olympic Village tradition. In recent interviews with NBC News, Olympians from years past said rooms tend to be small, defined in part by what gold medalist swimmer Mark Spitz characterized as a \"low-cost IKEA look.\"\n\nThis year, the bare-bones bedrooms were designed with an eye on climate consciousness and a relatively light carbon footprint. The athletes staying inside the village are dozing off on cardboard beds. No air conditioning systems were installed, though some athletes brought their own mobile AC units.\n\nIn a reply to Gauff's video, one TikTok user wanted to know how the 20-year-old tennis phenomenon was coping with all the cardboard. Gauff explained that she had it covered: \"archery team lended me a mattress topper.\"\n\nIn a comment on another TikTok user's post, Team USA women's gymnastics icon Simone Biles described the sleeping situation in blunt terms: \"the bed sucks...... BUT we are getting mattress toppers so hopefully it'll get better.\" Biles' reply was followed by the \"fingers crossed\" emoji.\n\nIn many cases, Olympic competitors enjoy all that life inside the village entails, from the 24/7 food service to the impromptu hangout sessions. \"I chose to stay in [the] village for the experience,\" Gauff explained in a reply on TikTok.\n\nBrian Boitano -- the gold medalist figure skater who competed at the 1984, 1988 and 1994 Games -- recently told NBC News that the close quarters fostered immediate social bonds. \"In Calgary, sharing that tiny apartment with seven guys -- we were such a tight unit, he said, \"and there was so much camaraderie.\"\n\nTeam USA, a spokesperson for the American tennis team, and the Paris 2024 organizing committee did not immediately reply to requests for comment Monday. In a video posted on YouTube two weeks ago, the Olympics said the \"sustainable beds are 100% made in France and will be fully recycled in France after the Games.\"\n\nGauff's tennis teammates were apparently not the only Paris competitors who left the official residential complex.\n\nSix members of South Korea's swimming squad departed and checked into a nearby hotel because they were concerned about delays on the buses that transport athletes from the village to their arenas, according to the Korea Times, an English-language newspaper.\n\n\"It usually takes about 40 to 45 minutes from the village to the arena, but it took us more than an hour and a half [on Thursday],\" South Korean swimmer Hwang Sun-woo told the newspaper. \"Windows were taped probably because they are worried about terrorist attacks. But something has to be done.\"\n\nHwang was quoted comparing the bus to a \"sauna\" because of the lack of air conditioning.\n\nThe South Korean national Olympic committee did not respond to a request for comment on the Korea Times article.\n\nOlympic competitors are not required to stay in the village. Michael Jordan and other members of the 1992 Dream Team -- the first U.S. Olympic basketball squad featuring professional players -- set up shop at the Ambassador Hotel during the 1992 Barcelona Games, for example.\n\nIt's a tradition subsequent men's basketball squads have followed.\n\n\"The last few times I've done the Olympics, we've spent our fair share in the Olympic Village and felt like a part of the group there,\" Kevin Durant, the Phoenix Suns player and a member of the U.S. men's national team, told USA Today. \"We stay outside of it, but we get our time right before the {"uri": "8249187606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "15:40:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T15:40:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T15:39:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3019607961177826, "url": "https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Stories/146977/donna-vekic-on-bianca-andreescu-bizarre-injury-thought-she-d-die-and-i-lost-my-focus/", "title": "Donna Vekic on Bianca Andreescu bizarre injury: Thought she'd die and I lost my focus", "body": "Vekic addresses Andreescu injuring herself in a bizarre way during their Paris Olympics match.\n\nDonna Vekic admitted to losing her concentration and focus after Bianca Andreescu's injury as the Croatian tennis star says she felt like the Canadian was \"going to die\" after she let out a painful scream during their Paris Olympics second-round clash.\n\nWith Andreescu down by a set and losing early in the second set, the 2019 US Open champion hit herself in the left thumb with a racket during a moment of frustration. After a 10-minute break and former world No. 4 Andreescu getting some help and treatment, the match continued.\n\nBut after being up by a set and having a 2-0 lead in the second set, Vekic lost four of the next five games as Andreescu went 4-3 up with the lead of a break. But just when it seemed that Andreescu was getting closer to forcing a decider, Vekic responded with back-to-back breaks in the eighth and 10th games to overturn the deficit and get the job done in two sets.\n\n\"In the first moment, I really thought she was going to retire. She let out such a scream that I thought she was going to die, but she continued to play normally. I actually lost my concentration after that, which should not have happened to me,\" Vekic told Croatian outlet Sportske Novosti.\n\n\"Then she started to slice more, which normally doesn't suit me. It took me a few games to adjust. And if I had lost that second set, I believe I would have returned to my normal game. Well, I'll be smarter the next time.\"\n\nBy beating Andreescu, recent Wimbledon semifinalist Vekic set up a round-of-16 meeting against No. 2 seed Coco Gauff.\n\n\"I have never played against Coco.
